The terror and brutality of war has been a subject of many movies for years. Many consider the 1998 Steven Spielberg movie Saving Private Ryan the best and most realistically brutal depiction of war. However, that may change with the recent release of Hacksaw Ridge. Directed by Mel Gibson and starring Andrew Garfield, this film outlines the story of Desmond Doss, a pacifist who joined the American army and saved many soldiers despite refusing to to use or carry any type of weapon. This film has incredible battle scenes with realistic, brutal and graphic onscreen deaths. The film's directing is clever in how it focuses on close ups on the soldiers and their deaths. There are few times when the camera shots display the overall army which makes the story feel more claustrophopic and personal. Having the film's story focus on the carnage and dead bodies on the battlefield also adds to the horror of war outside of the actual action of it. There are some extremely grotesque and graphic depictions of dead or dying bodies. The sounds on the battle also convey the horror and insanity of the battlefield. This atmosphere creates actual tension and suspension on the survival of the various characters of the film. The way the battlefield is depicted aides the heroics of Doss. This character is played exceptionally by Andrew Garfield. He gives possibly the best performance of his career. He is friendly and likable but also knows when he needs to stand up for himself. He conveys his beliefs in a way that makes him appear noble. He does not force his beliefs upon anyone or try to convert anyone, he simply wants to be able to practice them. This adherence to beliefs is an important message that is effectively expressed. The rest of the cast fits their role as well. Hugo Weaving actually gives a sincere heartfelt performance as Doss' alcoholic and war torn father. Weaving is able to depart from his normally villainous or evil performances to give an emotionally jarring performance as a man who is struggling with alcoholism and the abuse this causes his family. While his accent sounds off at times, he still is able to convey the emotions of a father attempting to make amends to his family and protect his sons from the destruction of war that he has experienced. Similarly, Sam Worthington as Doss' commanding officer has the most clear arch of the film and completely disappears into the character. Luke Bracey is also able to elevate his character above the generic bully character when he is given a backstory and starts to respect Doss and his philosophy. Possibly most interesting is Vince Vaughan as Doss' sergeant. The normally comedic actor who normally struggles in dramas, and has struggled in most of his comedies the past few years, gives a good performance. His combination of humorous insults and actual moments of intimidation makes Vaughan play to his comedic skills while not breaking the serious tone of the film. Aside from the performances and cinematography, possibly the most interesting aspect of the film is how accurate it is. Apparently, the real person this is based upon did not want a movie made about him since he was worried about accuracy. However, this movie is nearly completely accurate in every detail. With the exception of a few inaccuracies that can be attributed to the way the film presents the scenes, it is impressive how accurate this film tells this real life story. Unfortunately, the way the story is told is a negative aspect of the film. There are many characters arches that feel rushed or incomplete. Some characters, like Ross' brother who was extremely important in the beginning of the film, disappear entirely from the plot. Additionally, this film is two and a half hours and it honestly feels longer. This movie's pacing drags at various areas of the film. Particularly towards the end of the film the pacing slows and the scenes become repetitive. Also without spoiling anything, the ending displays what should be an important scene through precredit text which detracts from its impact. Hacksaw Ridge is a film that is able to balance pacifist, Christian morales with some of the mist realistic and brutal depictions of war in cinema history. Despite some pacing issues and rushed character arches, the film has great performances, particularly by Andrew Garfield, and is a great return of Mel Gibson as a director. I would recommend Hacksaw Ridge to those who want to be inspired by an incredible American hero who stuck to his beliefs even in adversity but are not made uncomfortable by extremely graphic violence and mutilated, decomposing corpses.

More-so than lingering on Mel Gibson's involvement with this film and its success, more attention should be focused on Andrew Garfield's emergence as a budding star actor.  in the tail of Hacksaw Ridge and Desmond Doss, Garfield portrays a man who stood tall for his convictions even when everyone around him was practically forcing him to do everything against them to survive in the Army.  What we learn from this film isn't an argument for or against religion, but to one's own faith in what you believe.  Whatever it is.

Hacksaw won't be billed as a top-level war-time film like the Saving Private Ryan's or Black Hawk Downs of the world, but it delivers a solid cut scene of one aspect of the entire war dealing with one specific incident.  At times, the pacing is tough to determine exactly how much time as passed.  Did all of this take place in two days?  A week?  A month?

What this movie did a fantastic job of was focusing on Doss's plight.  His story is incredible.  Whether they embellished some of it or not, you can't help but feel those pangs inside of you for there being someone like Doss on America's side in those times.

Unfortunately, because it devotes nearly all of its time to this one man's story, there are only flashes of building this movie into something on the level of the films I mentioned up above.  We get a brief glimpse at the team and supporting characters around him, but none of them get fleshed out or they run into one another leaving the audience trying to figure out if we met that character before or not.

The violence is poignant and pretty well done.  The sound effects are all there and the bang bang scenarios some of these guys were involved in really do come across as harrowing.

Hacksaw Ridge won't break any barriers on the war-front standard on the silver screen, but it does a fine job enlightening us to a real-life pacifist's journey through a troubled time back in WWII.

Hacksaw Ridge (2016): The Brutal Mel Gibson Is Back

If you are reading this review you have probably seen The Passion of the Christ (2004) or at least heard of it and the controversy it stirred over the gruesome brutality Mel Gibson unabashedly portrays on screen. For obvious reasons, the film could not wear the "true story" badge that, 12 years later, Hacksaw Ridge (2016) proudly does. This time, Gibson takes his Christ to World War II to tell the modern-day miracle of American corporal Desmond Doss, a religious and peaceful young man who despite his refusal to bear arms or commit any act of violence, saves the lives of 75 soldiers in his division during the Battle of Okinawa.

The film features an incredibly diverse cast; Andrew Garfield, Hugo Weaving, Sam Worthington, Rachel Griffiths, Luke Bracey and Vince Vaughn, all pushed to limits I never thought they would reach. Who would have thought that the sweet boy-next-door Peter Parker has been carrying so much unnoticed potential? He may not look like the real Desmond Doss at all, but his innocently childish face renders the purity of Doss's character, and his emotionally fierce performance conveys the vigor of his faith. However, the person whose presence is felt the most during the 140-minute-long movie is Mr. Gibson himself; his brutal and raw energy becomes the moving force behind every single shot. While watching the film, I caught myself unconsciously clenching my body in a fetus position as a way to fend off the violence on the screen. Gibson's violence is not the gory slaughterhouse kind that invests in feelings of disgust (that never gets me anyway); it is violence that brings our physical and human vulnerability to unprecedented proximity - he brutally invades the bubble of our reality to bring our insides out for everyone to see... meaningless, absurd, and vicious as they are.

Although it has been described as a "religious bomb," the way I see it, Hacksaw Ridge preaches faith not religion. I am well aware that Mel Gibson is an extremely religious individual, and I mean it dogmatically and aesthetically. Like it or not, you've got to respect him for his discipline as a director and his courageous indifference to Hollywood standards. In a time where miracles are ridiculed and our sole idea of heroes is sexy bodies in spandex suits whose superpowers are measured by how much damage they can inflict, Gibson shows us a real hero whose only superpower was his faith - a real hero who only wanted to save lives... all lives!

For those who could not understand his message the first time, Gibson is saying it again, louder and in a much more mature voice: we need to jump into the very heart of violence to really understand the powerful nature of love.

Hacksaw Ridge review. Well, I've found a new favourite Superhero film. That is absolutely what this war movie is, because the main character was a real life hero who stands in the company of very few amazing people. The movie starts feeling very much like Braveheart set in WW2. Lovely, noble people who fall in love and the whole thing feels warm and fuzzy. Be prepared though. That feeling doesn't last. The film takes its time to get to the action by setting up characters, family relationships, the tension in a small town and how important the main character's belief system is to him. Desmond Doss was an incredible human being who stayed true to his convictions against overwhelming odds, and then showed the world that faith can be your shield when you need to be brave. The climax of the movie comes by delivering one of my new favourite scenes from any movie. Doss stays alone when his whole company retreats to run into an artillery barrage to find his fallen friends. He is hunted by Japanese soldiers, chased into holes, is shot at by snipers and never picks up a weapon. Alone he saved 75 people that night. It is such an inspirational story that you come away feeling that the world is a different place. I wish I could have met this man and shook his hand. Hacksaw Ridge is one of the most gruesome and intense movies I have seen. Bodies are blown apart and cut in half by bullets, all without the levity that comes from a Quentin Tarantino film. Because of that I can't recommend this film to everyone. You may be too squeamish to watch some of the brutal, non-stop war scenes. But if you can see this movie you must. Desmond Doss deserves this sort of recognition and I know he would love to know that his story touched the lives of millions worldwide.

A few weeks ago today the film Hacksaw Ridge came out in theaters. Since I first saw the trailer for this months prior to that I was already sort of familiar with what the film was about. Mel Gibson has created a very well done film about a young man who refuses to fight but wants to help his country in its darkest hour. Andrew Garfield's Desmond Doss is a man who believes whole heartedly in the Word of God. Despite that and refusing to touch a gun Doss still wants to join the armed forces in fighting the Japanese overseas. After plenty of complications a troubles in keeping his morale during basic training he does end up among the ranks of the United States Marine Corps on Okinawa. Here the movie really comes to life with the absolutely relentless horrors of war time in 1945. Packed tightly with loud artillery and a few jump scares the audience and myself found ourselves on the edge of our seat the whole time.
The first act of the film was set in Desmond Doss's hometown of Lynchburg, Virginia. Times are changing in America, as everyone already knows, as World War II continues to rage on. Desmond's brother, Hal, feels the push to join and help his country so he goes to enlist himself. This is troublesome for the father of the Doss family as he is a veteran of the first World War. His scars, while not plainly visible, are there emotionally. Because he lost thereof his friends in the war he fears that he might lose his sons as well. This does not phase Desmond and he goes to enlist as a medic because he is a conscientious objector. Before he goes off to bootcamp he asks for his girlfriends hand in marriage, a girlfriend he had met only a few days earlier. In my opinion I thought this was probably the worst act of the film. I think it suffered mostly from being simply too long. A lot of the scenes in the first act were unnecessary in retrospect. Thought the light, lovable tone of the first act serves a purpose later in the film, many of the scenes were not needed. One thing that Mel Gibson did do well however is how he portrays the father Tom Doss (played by Hugo Weaving). Weaving's character is portrayed as both a drunk and an abuser of his family. After a fight between Desmond and Hal he beats Desmond which pushes their mother to reinforce the Sixth Commandment in their house. In another scene Tom attempts to murder his wife before Desmond intervenes and almost kills him. This leads both Desmond and Hal to disobey their father without second thought when they join the military. The Tom Doss character as a whole was very well done and though it seemed cliche at first it did serve a greater purpose.
The second act that took place at basic training for the 77th Infantry Division of the Marines. Vince Vaughn plays a tough and hard-nosed drill sergeant that doesn't take kindly to those who don't follow orders. Because Desmond Doss is assigned to Howell (Vince Vaughn) he turns the company against him even before he gives him a chance. This second act is a great preset for the looming battle ahead. This act doesn't fail where the last one did as it is excellently paced and even adds some humor into the film. This act also introduces the theme of never giving up on what you believe. Desmond Doss finds himself on trial for disobeying orders from his officer during this act. But he does not waiver his faith even in the face of jail time. Because he does this his father shows up vouching for him to fight and help the United States. The panel of officers who hold Desmond's trail have no choice but to oblige. This act was heartfelt and pulled at heartstrings even though we all knew what was coming next.
The final act of the film was by far the best and most powerful. When the Marines show up to Hacksaw Ridge it looks like a place out of a horror story. The only way in and out of the battle zone was up a ladder tied to the face of a cliff. At the top of the ladder what laid before the soldiers was nothing short of hell. Seeing as this movie central theme is faith in God this seems like only a fitting setting. The next forty-five minutes of the movie kept my heart racing the whole time. Because Mel Gibson did not use music through the first parts of the battle scene the sounds of gunfire and artillery and screaming filled the theatre. It was chilling to listen to while horrible scenes of people burning alive and explosions filled the screen. I think the movie that came before this probably made this last part of the film feel more uncomfortable. Because the rest of the movie had a sort of a lighthearted tone this counterbalanced this part of the film because it was so dark. Gibson did a fantastic job on the last act because he used Hacksaw Ridge as an extra character in the movie. The battle ground itself was a different entity than the rest and the main characters in the film wrestled with it for a majority of the movie. I think it also served as a biblical tie for Desmond Doss. Where the first part of his life in Lynchburg with his wife and his family might have been heaven, Hacksaw Ridge was most certainly hell. And as he walked through hell, still following the Word of God and keeping true to himself, is when he had his finest hour. On the ridge Doss saved countless men, most of them had written him off early in bootcamp. Another biblical tie can be found in that as well. One of the Bibles most famous phrases is "turn the other cheek" and Desmond Doss does that as he saves his friends that once heckled him and doubted him earlier.
In the end, when me anomy friends I went to see it with were pleasantly surprised. Mel Gibson masterfully mixed two of his most famous films, We Were Soldiers and Passion of the Christ, and made an even better film than those two. Gibson, who rarely disappoints left me and my friends more appreciative of our veterans. I expected a lackluster film, to be honest. I expected a film to come out this late in the year to merely a plea for Oscars. But, in fact, it wasn't and it was film that I would even go see again. At some points it dragged in and at others it was hard to watch but like I said before in the end you leave with a new appreciation for our soldiers. Mel Gibson and his crew have fluently stitched together a hearty war film with a theme so tender that it pulls at you heart and leaves close to tears. Hacksaw Ridge was probably one of the better movies I have seen in my lifetime.

Ladies and gentleman, Mel Gibson is back making movies. This time he directs a WW2 film that tells the true story of pacifist medic named Desmond Doss, who saved the lives of 75 men during "The Battle of Okinawa." This film may not rank up with Mel Gibson's best movies but its got a lot of heart and has some of the most brutal war scenes you will see to date. 
  Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield) is a Christian man who comes from an abusive home, falls in love, and goes to war. We see this kinda stories often but this one is a little different. During his enlistment as a medic, he refuses to use a rifle. His moral beliefs are then tested when he is in the hellfire of battle. 
  Andrew Garfield does an extremely well job with Desmond's character. He is likable and committed to his beliefs. His accent is also sharp and mannerisms are very believable. The other two performances that really stood out was Vince Vaughn as Sergeant Howell and Hugo Weaving as Tom Doss (Desmond's father.) Vince Vaughn starts out as a Sergeant in boot camp and has some funny scenes but plays a serious man. He usually doesn't take on too many serious roles but this one was one of his best. Hugo Weaving is also surprisingly good. He is an alcoholic father, suffering from PTSD. His emotions are haunting and Hugo plays him with such commitment. 
  Now this movie does start off slow. We see Desmond's life and how he falls in love with Dorothy (Teresa Palmer) as well as his time in boot camp. When we finally get to the battle scenes, they are often terrifying and it keeps you on the edge. This is real gruesome stuff and uses shocking imagery instead of glorifying action. It's realistic and brutal and forces us as viewers to witness how war really is. However, despite its realism of battle the direction plays it safe in using traditional camera work and not much creativity in the cinematography like "Saving Private Ryan (1998)" did. 
  Now this movie is more than just warfare but it's about love, faith, and courage. Desmond was a remarkable man staying true to his beliefs of god. He saved many lives regardless of fatigue and gunfire. This story is remarkable. There are some problems I have with it, though. The religious themes are big in this movie. Sometimes it feels like its suppose to be a moral movie of pacification, but we get a film full of gore and violence. It's hard to get the sense of what it wants to be but alas it's just the true story of a man who saved many lives. Then I do have some issues with the special effects used. There is a scene where you see cannons firing from battleships that don't look realistic. The CGI did not look good in those scenes, as well as some other scenes which are harder to notice but they could have done a better job. There is also some things that are not in the movie such as Desmond's actions in previous battles. We only see his couple days at Hacksaw Ridge, which is fine but I did wanna see more of his efforts before hand. 
  I'm giving this review a little late since it's been in theaters for awhile, but I'm glad I got to see it. This movie is well-acted and will often leave you tearing up or cringing. It's haunting and beautiful showing that one man can make a difference. It shows that there is light in all the fog of the world. Go see it, if you haven't already because you don't wanna miss this one.

From the beginning to the end, this movie keeps your attention and it is very difficult to move away from the screen. Mr. Mel Gibson had done an excellent job bringing forth a discussion not easy to have. A conscience objector in the military is not an easy connotation to add to one's name. The main protagonist is a conscience objector. He has made a decision to do his part for the war effort. However he refuses to use a weapon to kill. He wants to save lives. Of course his superiors looked at him as a coward. The Army does his best to get him removed from its ranks.  But they can't stop him. The private and medic in the Army managed to finish his training and goes to Korea with his platoon.  The battle is ferocious and the Japanese inflicts death in high numbers to the Americans.  Under enemy fire the medic saves 75 wounded soldiers. He becomes a hero.
What makes the movie so extraordinary is a correlation of a traumatic childhood due to the main character' father own demons.  The father too fought in the field of France during WWI. Hunted by the ghosts of war, the father seeks refuge in alcohol. The protagonist has witnessed violence in his family, and once almost kills his brother. One night he stops his father from being violent to his mother. Something stirs in his heart and he makes a decision to bring forth repentance and a solid faith. This faith is very clear when he rescued the wounded soldiers. He prays to God for the strength needed to save each injured soldier. 
There is one more aspect related to his faith. Before he leaves for training, his girlfriend and later on wife gives him a Bible. He holds on to the Bible and he is never far from the book and prayers. I think he understood that when hell is ahead, you better hold on to God to do what others deemed impossible. To enter hell and walk the same route backwards carrying wounded men on small shoulders, 75 times, without firing a single bullet, requires the deliverance of the power from above - Great movie.

A good old-fashioned war drama about true-life young American hero in WW2 who didn't believe in killing a man or even holding a gun... but still wanted to serve his country so became a battlefield medic instead.

He rescued a lot of fellow soldiers and got Medal of Honor without shooting out a single bullet. Starring Andrew Garfield - and before you google or IMDB him, yes, he's the current Spider-Man.

Hacksaw Ridge doesn't really bring anything fresh to the war drama table. But it's not necessarily a bad thing because for all the cliches and simpleness it also manages to be one of those beautiful event movies which win us over by just how well they are put together in every aspect.

The battle scenes are as brutal and eye-catching as expected but I especially liked how the movie manages to work on different levels.

It reminds us that war was hell before it was all entertainment for the younger generations - but it also manages to be sweet and kind of feel-good, praising the good in our souls which can make us rise to the occasion and make the most of the bad situation. And, of course, action fans will not leave disappointed either.

It's also amazing how soulful performances the actors offer based on quite shallow one-dimensional characters.

Garfield is a true star here, giving his all as a boy not quite a man but ready to do man's job - all starry-eyed, idealistic and physically resembling a young calf at times - yet never giving up on personal quest to be worthy of own's ideals. You will totally buy him as a young American hero.

The supporting cast is strong too, especially Hugo Weaving as the hero's troubled father and Vince Vaugh as sgt Howell.

It is kind of ironic that after years and years of yawn-inducing talky roles in mostly mediocre comedies, Vaughn has found new calling in serious, violent stories such as "Hacksaw Ridge" and the mafia man in HBO's "True Detective's" season 2.

This is also kind of comeback/renewal for Mel Gibson, one of the more likable movie stars from the end of 1970's to the beginning of 2000's.

In the middle of 2000's, he suddenly stopped acting, directed two violent historical movies ("Passion of the Christ", "Apocalypto") and turned from a longtime family man and father of seven to seemingly homicidal maniac, if we believe the news and notorious recordings made by his neighbors, leaked to web.

He's returned to acting in 2010 but has been keeping lower darker indie-er profile ever since, so many of you have probably not seen him in anything new. Except maybe cameo-ing in Machete 2 and The Expendables 3. This time, he's "only" director and does a marvellous job at that, putting everything together and wringing the most out of the cast.

"Hacksaw Ridge" may not be remembered as one of the greats in crowded war movie genre but it's working beautifully in ts own right. Two hours well spent.

When it comes to genres, some are just so oversaturated or done so well before that it would seem difficult to do something different and make an impression. The war genre is such a category where it has been done to death, being one of cinemas earliest forays with the likes of 1930s All Quiet on the Western Front to 1970s Apocalypse Now or the 1998 double effort of The Thin Red Line or Saving Private Ryan. All classics in their own right. Although Mel Gibson's 2016 Hacksaw Ridge doesn't quite stack up amongst the aforementioned films, the award-winning director has produced an accomplished work that is moving, uplifting and depicts the strength of the human spirit. With a very clever premise that is based on a true story (put someone in a war who doesn't believe in violence), the content shown is horrifying and hasn't been expressed in the cinematic medium quite like this. Gibson manages to keep the tone (and tension) at a perfect balance which is anchored by great performances by Andrew Garfield, Sam Worthington, Hugo Weaving, Luke Bracey (quickly making you forget about 2015s Point Break) and Vince Vaughn. Being out of the directing game since 2006s (under-appreciated) Apocalypto, Gibson has dusted off his hat and has again shown his amazing ability with Hacksaw Ridge-a good old fashioned picture that will impress and is a worthy entry in the war genre.

Damn you, Mel Gibson! You're making it very hard for me to continue hating you. For sure, I'll never forget your anti-Semitic rants or your unwavering support for your father after his own outspoken statements denying the Holocaust. But that's history and it seems that you're now on a path of redemption, keeping your racist opinions to yourself and focusing on your craft. Your latest film, HACKSAW RIDGE, is mighty good and you deserve the praise you're receiving for it. Is it worthy of a Best Picture Oscar (R) though, or are you deserving of a Best Director Oscar (R)? Hollywood does love a comeback, which is what you have achieved with this film but Hollywood is also controlled by Jews (sez you) and, while we like to forgive, we don't like to forget. It would seem that Jewish Hollywood has given you that most Christian of attributes - forgiveness, but we'll have to wait until the end of February to find out how forgetful the Academy voters are.

Now about your film, it is one of the best films I've seen so far this year but it's not without its weaknesses. I understand that it tells the true story (as opposed to being "based on a true story", which implies some element of fiction) of Desmond Doss, an American pacifist combat medic in WWII, who became the first conscientious objector to be awarded the Medal of Honor, for service above and beyond the call of duty. Doss (played by Andrew Garfield, THE SOCIAL NETWORK) was a Seventh-day Adventist. When America entered the war following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, young men and women all over the country enlisted to fight. Doss also wanted to serve his country but he steadfastly refused to carry or use a firearm or weapons of any kind. This stance raised the ire of both his sergeant (played by Vince Vaughn, WEDDING CRASHERS) and captain (Sam Worthington, AVATAR), who tried to get him drummed out of the army on a Section 8 discharge. When that didn't work, they had Doss arrested and tried for insubordination. Doss' father (played by Hugo Weaving, THE DRESSMAKER) came to the rescue though. A veteran of WWI, the elder Doss reached out to his former commanding officer who was by that point a general. Pacifism, it turns out, is protected under the US constitution. Although Doss was allowed to return to his unit, he still faced a huge hurdle from his colleagues who didn't like him or trust him.

All that changed when the unit was shipped off to Japan to participate in the Battle of Okinawa. There, they had to climb the cliff face of the Maeda Escarpment, nicknamed "Hacksaw Ridge", and engage the enemy who was well ensconced on the top. It was a brutal campaign that lasted for weeks (or days, as depicted in the film) with heavy casualties on both sides. During a lull in the fighting, Doss scurried around collecting his wounded comrades and rappelling them down the cliff face to shocked medics below. Working throughout the night, he single-handedly rescued over 75 soldiers, many of whom were so badly injured they most certainly would have died from their wounds if not for Doss' heroism.

It's an amazing story that one wonders why it wasn't told ages ago. It turns out that various efforts had been made over the years to bring Doss' story to the big screen but for a number of reasons it never happened. For starters, the screenplay sat in "Development Hell" for over a decade. Gibson himself turned down the opportunity to direct the film twice before finally agreeing to do it. Then there was a problem with funding. In the end, production took place in Australia with a largely local cast (not to mention the director himself) in order to qualify for government tax credits there.

Unfortunately, all these factors played into some of the film's shortcomings. The story is very old fashioned and seems to be somewhat anachronous for today's audiences. World War II ended 71 years ago and the reasons for going to war have changed since then. Could a Doss exist in today's world of Iraq, Afghanistan, the Taliban and ISIS? All the Australian actors putting on their best American accents, not to mention Virginian accents for some of them, is a bit strange too. And the scenes of Fort Jackson in South Carolina are too Disney-fied to seem real. On the plus side, Garfield arguably does his best work ever bringing a Forrest Gump-like charm to Doss. If it weren't for the footage at the end of the film of the real Doss (taken before his died in 2006), we would think Garfield's portrayal was too hokey to be believed but we can see that the actor got the character right.

As for Gibson, he brings his usual heavy-handed mix of gratuitous violence, blood and Christian imagery to the film. There is no shortage of scenes of mangled bodies displayed in all their glory while rats run around feasting on the entrails. War is hell and nothing is held back to remind us of that. There is also plenty in the film that will give ministers and preachers heaps of sermon fodder for months to come. Characters seek forgiveness, find redemption and turn to G-d throughout the story, but the most blatant image comes at the end of the film when Doss himself is hoisted down the cliff face after being on the receiving end of a Japanese bullet. Injured and bloody, the camera shoots Garfield from below as if Doss is ascending to heaven as his earthly work is complete. The symbolism doesn't get more obvious than that. But, to his credit, Gibson knows how to tell a story and keep it interesting throughout.

All in all, HACKSAW RIDGE is thrillingly good entertainment though. If you can handle the religious overtones not to mention the gore, it's well worth your time and money. Damn you, Mel Gibson! It looks like you're back.

Serving your country.  Based on a true story, this is about a combat medic in World War II named Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield).  He did not believe in killing and refused to carry a gun, but he also wanted to do the honorable thing for the United States in wartime.  This is his story about how he completed his training and saved a ton of lives in Japan against all odds.  I think that there is one reason why this isn't being pushed harder as the next Saving Private Ryan and that solely is because this is directed by Mad Mel Gibson.  You can say what you will about the man's personal life, heaven knows that the media has, but the man flat out knows how to make a tense movie, and that is exactly what he has done with Hacksaw Ridge.  Along with Gibson, there's a bunch of people here who desperately need a hit.  Andrew Garfield has got the talent, but Spider-Man did not pan out like he thought it would, and you can tell that he wants to put that behind him and is ready to be taken seriously.  Sam Worthington is arguably the most generic action star next to Jai Courtney, and he's actually inspired in this.  The person who impressed me the most in this would have to be Vince Vaughn.  I do not consider to be myself a big fan of his comedy, and more often than not, I actually don't care for his movies at all.  He knocked it out of the park in this.  He plays a sergeant, and while he doesn't take it to those extreme dehumanizing levels that R. Lee Ermey did in Full Metal Jacket, he does bring exactly what is needed for this role.  In fact, if he did push the envelope further, it would have made this feel less grounded in reality, so I have more respect for Vaughn for knowing where to draw the line.  This is going to come off as very high praise, but this is like the first half of Full Metal Jacket meeting the first 15 minutes of Saving Private Ryan.  While it is never as groundbreakingly brilliant as those two movies to be sure, it really isn't that far off.  In addition to being this brutal, traumatizing war movie, it does also have a religious angle to it as well.  Even though I don't consider myself to be very religious or spiritual, I really appreciated the subtlety to it, and this never feels the urge to bash you over the head with Jesus.  It also helps to give the character of Doss a plentiful amount of dimension.  He's a man with a code, which is always a relatable thing in movies; it's why Westerns usually work as well as they do, and it is also why Batman is so cool, but I digress.  This is excellently made, and there is some terrific sound mixing that really made me feel physically ill when everything started to go down.  It puts you right there in the trenches with the soldiers, and I was jumpy from the moment they ascended the ridge all the way to the end credits rolling.  I love the moral quandary presented to this man, and I think this is one of the best movies of the year.

Powerful war film from director Mel Gibson. I always feel like I have to qualify my admiration for Gibson as a director due to his personal views, attitudes, and actions, but he is an amazing filmmaker. In this film, Gibson tells the true-life story of WWII American Army Medic Desmond T. Doss, who served in the Pacific theater as a contentious objector, refusing to pick-up a gun, but who earned a Medal of Honor for single handedly saving 75 wounded soldiers. The film does follow the standard "Sands of Iwo Jima" formula of back home, to boot camp, to the big battle. Although the film does dip into cliches at times, Andrew Garfield's performance is so sincere, he transcends the cliches and manages to make the film feel true and honest despite being corny at times. Once the film gets to the battle scenes, there is nothing corny about this film. Gibson is a smart director, but his real gift is shooting action and battle scenes. As with "Braveheart," the battle scenes in this film are something truly to behold. They are terrifying, brutal, and absolute visceral experiences. Stephen Spielberg directed the very memorable and intense US invasion of Normandy, but that is nothing compared to the battle scenes in this film. The battle scenes here are worthy comparison to those in Stanley Kubrick's "Paths of Glory." I honestly do not think war has ever been depicted on film in such brutal terms before. I'm not sure I would classify this film as an anti-war film, but I think it is more about bravery and sticking to your beliefs, though the depiction of the horrors of war are pretty rough. The real life Desmond Doss turned down offers to make a movie of his heroics for decades because he did not think Hollywood would give an accurate depiction of war. There's no mistaking that this film would have met Doss' standard for not glamorizing war.

The second world war has been depicted on film hundreds of times over the past 70 or so years, with some adaptations earning a place in cinematic history while others barely registered as a blip on the radar. In his first time back in the director's chair since 2006's 'Apocalypto,' Mel Gibson brings to life the story of conscientious objector-turned-Medal of Honor recipient Private Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield) - an army medic who single-handedly saved the lives of dozens of fellow soldiers without firing a single shot.

Now, many in Hollywood can hide behind the tired phrase "based on a true story," but in this case, the "based on" is not needed. As many will concede, films that have strong storylines and themes that tie what happens on-screen together in a coherent way are generally thought to be among the better ones when compared with mindless, messy movies that we often see. In 'Ridge,' however, Private Doss' story is so compelling that everything from his violent upbringing with his drunkard father to his realization that his faith calls for never harming another living thing makes for a great central focus in 'Ridge.' In fact, Garfield's performance is such a step up from what he's shown audiences in the past that it's no wonder there's a lot of Oscar buzz around him at the moment.

While a film about the events on Hacksaw Ridge in Okinawa would not have been as strong without an individual like Doss as the focus, the supporting cast definitely brings its A-game here. Sam Worthington stands out for his portrayal as a nay-saying captain who at first cannot accept Doss' aversion to holding a weapon, while Vince Vaughn takes another step toward diversifying his acting portfolio in a serious role as a drill sergeant that pales in comparison to the likes of 'Full Metal Jacket's Gunnery Sargent Hartman. Theresa Palmer also impresses in her supporting role as Doss' love interest, but it is Hugo Weaving who steals the show as Tom Doss - a WWI veteran who causes his family so much pain, yet comes through in a big way when he needs to most.

Aside from the strong story and above-average acting, 'Ridge' benefits from amazing cinematography, as the horrors of war are captured in life-like reality. While it's unfair to put it in the same league as 'Saving Private Ryan,' 'Ridge' is one of the most brutal glimpses into what it was like to engage in hand-to-hand combat in WWII, and viewers almost feel like they are standing on Okinawa watching everything go down - for better or worse. There are also a few moments that are either so crazy or horrible that it's hard to imagine they're true, and while Hollywood is of course known for exaggerating plot points to drive something home, you can't help but imagine the majority of what transpires did in fact happen. And, finally, the score is one that stays with you long after you've seen the film - always a good sign.

It's true that many have a hard time looking beyond Mel Gibson's personal shortcomings, and will either refuse to see 'Hacksaw Ridge' or admit that it's any good. Despite this, there's no denying that this film is one of the best entries in the war/combat genre in a long, long time, and should absolutely be considered a frontrunner for the forthcoming Academy Awards. By communicating a story that resonates globally and focusing on themes such as respect for life, standing up for your beliefs and the "no man left behind" mentality, 'Hacksaw Ridge' is a film that has the potential to (and should be) admired and celebrated universally.

Spoilers ahead. This afternoon I figured I would take in a movie and then find seven or so geocaches before it got too dark. I wanted to see Hacksaw Ridge for a while since the previews looked okay, and I knew little to nothing about the film. In fact I had no idea it was based on a true story (spoiler). Anyway, Hacksaw Ridge follows the story of Desmond Doss, who because he was a Seventh Day Adventist, refused to use a weapon in war... and he got away with it. He goes to Okinawa (apparently not the only places he went, but we don't see the other places) and has to fight for Hacksaw Ridge, a large cliff area the Japanese heavily defend. 
The movie shows Doss's past, and his enlistment in basic training and how he refuses to hold a weapon and faces a couple of beatforces including Vince Vaughn, his drill sergeant. 
I was honestly waiting for the film to speed up. I'm like, I realize that some of this is important, but for the most part the first half is slow. Then we go to the battle scenes, which were well done aside from the sheer ridiculousness of it all. I told my brother that some of it seemed unrealistic, as in there is no way in hell people would survive that. But I guess they did. There are some brutal scenes, and a lot of body parts all over. This was first shown to us in Saving Private Ryan, and by now, its got to the point where it's like yeah, I know, war is hell. Trying to gross me out like Fury did doesn't earn you points. I care more about story than gore.
I did see a couple of continuity errors, and people getting shot only to be okay later. I was also confused with the two guys who look like Sam Worthington. I couldn't tell them apart at times, especially when their helmets were on. 
The film ends kind of hea. Andrew Garfield gets his bible back, and he gets stuck halfway down the cliff but he's okay. He just says heaaa really loud and then the film goes into interviews with the real life people. It was only at the very end did I realize that the events in this film really happened. It kind of improved my outlook on the film at that point. Had I known that earlier, I may not have thought how ridiculous some of the action was.

I thought the acting was decent, although I'm confused with some of the casting. I don't see Vince Vaughn as a drill sergeant. Granted he did the best he could with his short part, but hea. Sam Worthington is a beatforce (which is why he was in Terminator), and so are some of the other cast members. I'm not really sure what to think about Andrew Garfield. Hacksaw Ridge is a competent World War II film that tells the story of Desmond T. Doss, a conscientious objector and Seventh-Day Adventist who refused to carry a weapon, even during basic training.  His commitment to pacifism earned him the ire of his superiors and the enmity of his fellow recruits.  After brutal hazing and a court martial, Doss was allowed to train as a combat medic and would participate in the Battle of Okinawa, where he saved the lives of over 75 men and would later receive the Medal of Honor for his uncommon valor.  He was an exceptional human being and a Virginian too!  What makes Hacksaw Ridge work as a film is the commitment of its director Mel Gibson, and Andrew Garfield as Doss in the kind of earnest and heartfelt performance you don't get much of these days.  Hacksaw Ridge also reflects the director's religious beliefs, as the main character's arc and the overall theme of the movie center around Christian redemption and grace.  But it also reflects Gibson's fetish for gory violence and ambiguous moralizing.  Some may complain of murky messaging, but I felt it was consistent enough to not break the picture.  I don't know if it ranks with the best of WWII films (Fury may be the best post-Saving Private Ryan film) but it's good enough to warrant a viewing.

This is one of the most violent war movies I've ever seen! You may be thinking, "What in the world could beat that opening scene in Saving Private Ryan?" This can. Not only was this film intense to a whole other level, this film has some amazing heart and emotion behind it. Andrew Garfield is spectacular as Desmond Doss. He is so likable and so empathetic and he really caries this movie. From what he had to endure for simply refusing to touch a gun to his heroics on the battle field, we  are right there with him. You just can't help but smile when he is on screen and falling in love with a nurse at the local hospital. He isn't the only good actor in this movie, though. Hugo Weaving, Sam Worthington, and even Vince Vaughn are really well played and executed in this film. As for the battle scenes, you can watch all the war movies out there, (Saving Private Ryan, Apocalypse Now, Fury, Black Hawk Down, American Sniper, you name it) you have never seen violence and intensity like this on screen. My jaw was on the floor. Mel Gibson really knows how to up the violence, the bloodshed and the pure shock value to whatever he films. Whether it be a battle in Middle Ages Scotland or the Death of Jesus Christ, Mel Gibson knows how to deliver the blood! Although, why this film? Why this story to tell? The moral of the story is that decent people in this world do exist who only want to help other people. How one man's courage and faith can save lives. Yes, this movie has some pretty heavy religious overtones to it, but when you see Desmond Doss running back to rescue all the wounded soldiers on the ground and praying to god for him to save "just one more" it's powerful stuff! That's the best way to explain this film, "powerful". How are the human relationships? Powerful. How is the emotion behind the events of the story and the actions of the characters? Powerful. Do you feel the death toll of war and the horrors of being on the battle field? YES, YOU DO! A powerful, powerful film that will move you in ways very few films can!

HACKSAW RIDGE-2016(R)-Nov. 20.
By:Clem The Movie Guy.

With all of the horrifying news stories we read involving gun violence, it is not surprising that there are those people who believe that we shouldn't be carrying firearms of any kind. One such person was Medal of Honor recipient & WWII veteran Desmond Doss. Hacksaw Ridge is the inspiring true story of one man's courage & conviction which led to his serving his country & saving the lives of seventy-five men in battle without ever carrying a weapon. The Amazing Spider-Man's Andrew Garfield stars as Desmond Doss, a young man from Virginia with a strong belief in God. Doss enlisted in the army as a medic to save lives rather than take them. During Basis Training under Sergeant Howell (Vince Vaughn) Doss' beliefs cause him to be subjected to physical & mental torture by his fellow soldiers who want to see him discharged. Directed by Mel Gibson from the screenplay written by Andrew Knight & Robert Schenkkan, Hacksaw Ridge is one of the most powerfully intense & captivating war films that I have seen. The battle scenes were gripping & gruesome. Andrew Garfield gives the best performance of his career. The performances from Vince Vaughan along with Tom Worthington as Captain Glover, Teresa Palmer as Nurse Dorothy Schutte, Hugo Weaving & Rachel Griffiths as Tom & Bertha, Doss' parents were all sensational. Look for Hacksaw Ridge to receive some major award consideration, including Best Picture, Mel Gibson for Best Director & Andrew Garfield for Best Actor. Hacksaw Ridge is a MUST SEE FILM.

Hacksaw Ridge: This is the emotionally moving, astounding true story of US Army Medic Desmond Doss, the only conscientious objector to receive the Medal of Honor in World War II.  Andrew Garfield, in what very well could be an Oscar winning performance, brings a powerful humanity to Doss, both in the film's first half, which focuses on his struggle to remain in the army while remaining true to his personal convictions, and in the second half, which showcases his amazing heroics amidst some of the most graphic and realistic depictions of WWII battle since 1998's Saving Private Ryan. Say what you will about Mel Gibson's personal demons - he can still direct one heck of a movie. Hugo Weaving is outstanding as Doss' father. The ending, and its archival interview with Doss, will choke you up. One of the year's best. A+

My Dad was nice enough to take me to see Hacksaw Ridge tonight. I went in with such high hopes, after all, how could I not? Look at the amazing WWII movies that have come before it! Movies like, Saving Private Ryan, Fury, Schindlers' List, and the HBO miniseries' like Band of Brothers and The Pacific! Unfortunately, for me, Hacksaw Ridge belongs beside Pearl Harbor. (warning, spoilers) Let me preference this, again, by saying this is just my opinion. Dad absolutely loved this movie and I'm glad that he did. But in my opinion, the religious aspect of Hacksaw Ridge was WAY too heavy-handed. What the real Pfc. Desmond T. Doss did during the taking of Okinawa was heroic in every sense of the word. But Mr. Gibson took his story and made it about his religion. Every chance he got, Gibson reminded me that "oh hey remember how I made Passion of the Christ and how I'm super Christian now? Well here's another slow motion shot or mention of Doss' bible! Here's another shot of him reading his bible! Here's another scene of his fellow soldiers mentioning his bible!"
And while it's true, many men in WWII were very religious. However, you can make that part of a character without it being his main focal point. For example, Joseph Mazzello's portrayal of Eugine Sledge in The Pacific. He was a deeply religious man but it wasn't his only character trait. Also, the effort Mr. Gibson takes to make the messiah out of Doss was way too heavy-handed as well. Yes, the man himself is a hero. But tell the story of the man, the man who actually did these incredibly heroic things. The things that made him worthy of the Medal of Honor. Don't make it so his religion is what won him the Medal of Honor. 
My second problem with the movie...the violence was far too comic. Slow motion explosions, slow motion body parts ripping across the screen, slow motion point of view shots from the side of a machine gun as it rips through Japanese soldiers. Oh and of course, a slow motion scene of, who I assume was, Mitsuru Ushijima committing seppuku as Okinawa fell around him. You know how Micheal Bay takes his movies and just makes them into 2+ hours of explosions? Well Mel Gibson now does the same thing except with blood and gore. Not saying that there wasn't horrific blood and gore on the sands of Okinawa, but the way it was executed in this movie was absolutely over the top and, to a point, comical. Oh and also, I counted at least 3 guys pulling grenade pins out with their teeth. Hasn't this been decided that this is the stupidest thing ever in war movies?? Those pins will rip your teeth out before they come out of a grenade! And Gibson decided to put this into his movie not once, not twice, but three times!!!
In closing...I went into this movie with such high hopes but left it feeling disappointed. Mr. Gibson's religion was shoved down my mouth almost more than when I went to see The Passion. The violence was done not to show the horror of war, but to show how realistic and cool blood, guts and limbs can look when they're flying through the air in super slow motion. If you liked Hacksaw Ridge, I certainly don't want to take that away from you. Nor do I put you down for liking it. In my opinion, it feel very very short of my expectations. Here's hoping Dunkirk is awesome.

#2. Hacksaw Ridge - 5/5 Stars

I recently went to a symposium about the role of men in society. One prevalent point was that men were both the main perpetrators and the main victims of violent crimes. It brought forward the role that violence plays in the development of a young man. In the olden days, a man was expected to be able to fight off intruders and wrongdoers and should the need arise, be physically capable of going to war against a hostile nation.

Our society has changed to some extent, but the role of violence in a young boy's development is still present. Its not uncommon for some friend groups to insist that the guys know how to fight and for the girls to like a guy she can feel physically secure with. It's even seen in our modern role models, especially in the recent domination of superhero films. Very often its guys who use violence in order to save the world. These societal pressures give the impression to young boys that violence is good and necessary.

Hacksaw Ridge is about an army medic in World War II who was a conscientious objector, that is, he refused to use violence or carry a weapon. He saw that the world was suffering and decided that it was his duty to help in any way that he can. The first half of the movie dealt with the constant opposition he faced, not from the Axis powers, but from his own commanding officers who did not see him as valuable. He only had value if he could fight, a belief that would be true for soldiers and men in general at the time.

The second half of the movie shows him on the Pacific Front, having been allowed to go to war without a weapon. The battle can be described as a nightmare. Bullets flying everywhere, men being shot and dismembered and death far as the eye can see. Soldiers who were happy and prideful in the first half of the movie were reduced to either a corpse on a beach or a broken and injured shell. Was this what they were excited for? Was this what our main character fought to experience? Was this the great heroic journey that they were sold? The answer is no, and from these trials a true hero emerged.
For the remainder of the movie, we witness Desmond attempt to save as many lives as possible. Picking up wounded bodies, carrying them to the cliff edge and lowering them using a pulley to the command centre below, Desmond saves lives upon lives, regardless of whether they were friendly or not. "Lord let me save just one more" he would say as he bravely pushed himself into the battlefield, tired, weary but not broken. In the end, he is deemed a hero having saved the lives of dozens of men, by the same officers who stood against him. And he does this without firing a single shot.

Hacksaw Ridge does something unique. It shows young boys that heroism comes in many ways. You don't need to fight to be a hero. While violence was necessary in World War II, Desmond did not need to go against his morals to prove his worth. This could have been a great movie, but got caught up in the current form of Hollywood storytelling.  The movie provides background and a needless love story, that do little to advance the plot.

The movie spends way too long extending the main character's origins, while not developing the characters we're supposed to care about him saving.  

The scenes where he happily races up a mountain with his brother, then smashes a brick into his head minutes later turn out to have nothing to do with his abhorrence to violence.  We find out hours later that his promise to never pick up a gun came from a moment where his dad pulled a gun out during a fight with his mom, and after Doss wrestled it away he "murdered his dad in his heart".

And as is typical with many movies, a cheesy love story was thrown in for good measure.  We didn't need to follow his courtship of Dorothy, especially when it's smushed in there unnaturally to provide a "sense of motivation".  Not every movie needs a love story Hollywood.

This movie should have started with Doss at boot camp, and with a little exposition we could have been brought up to speed with his reasons for being a conscientious objector.  I never really felt connected to the other soldiers, even Vince Vaughn who felt super out of place as a drill instructor/company sergeant.

Desmond is supposed to have been compelled to enlist after the bombing of Pear Harbor, but the bombing or its impact on the people in Desmond's community is never shown.  We do get to see a newsreel of the Nazis when Doss and Dorothy are at the movies, but his reaction is fleeting.  There is no moment where it shows him driven into action by world events.

It also would have been good to get some time devoted to showing us the importance of taking the ridge.  What we get is a sentence along the line of "Take the ridge to take Okinawa; Take Okinawa to take Tokyo".

The enemy is the typical generic army.  There is one scene where the Japanese commander, while facing defeat, chooses to commit seppuku, but we don't get to know him, or the purpose of the ritual so it doesn't really matter.

The heart of the movie was Doss going into a brutal battle, refusing to carry a weapon, and after his unit retreated, stayed on the ridge saving as many wounded as he could.  After risking his life, and proving himself a hero, he goes back into Hell with his unit again to complete the mission.

The movie ends with some real life interviews with Desmond Doss, his brother Hal, and some of the men who survived taking the ridge.  God bless all those brave men who fought to protect a free world.

It's been 10 years since Mel Gibson has been behind the camera and in the director's chair since his 2006 ground breaker "Apocalypto," and boy was it worth the wait. We all know the story by now of Mel Gibson's troubles over the last ten years, even while he was making "Apocalypto," but now it's time to movie on and embrace the true fact that Mel Gibson is back! And thank god! The movie business just isn't the same without him, and as a huge fan of his, I must say that I am very grateful he's back in the game. Mel Gibson comes back strong with his World War 2 movie "Hacksaw Ridge," which tells the story of Pvt. Desmond Doss, a combat medic who is also a conscientious objector. Who refuses to carry a weapon in the brutal war between America and the Japan. It causes quite a bit of uproar against his combat buddies, since they are all relying on each other to save each other's lives by killing the enemy. And the fact that Doss refuses to carry a weapon because of his strong religious beliefs, raises many eyebrows and questions to why he will not carry a fire arm in the mist of battle against the Japanese. The truth is that there is a major back story to why Doss refuses to carry a weapon, and it all goes back to his childhood. Mel Gibson tells the back story beautifully! I won't give too much away, but it all has to do with the days of being a kid and witnessing his father played brilliantly by Hugo Weaving, feeling the tremendous pain of the things he saw fighting the Germans in World War 1. And sadly wishing he wasn't alive, and hating himself tremendously through the process of indulging in alcohol to try and kill the pain. Because of this, an incident happens not only between Doss and his father, but with his younger brother that tremendously impacts Doss as a child. Making him realize that to take another human life is a tremendous sin. Which is what leads him to becoming the man, and the hero who ends up saving countless lives in the battle of Okinawa, 1945. Andrew Garfield of Spider-Man fame and David Fincher's "The Social Network," which was his break out performance; takes on the title role of Desmond Doss. And I must say, he's definitely up for an Oscar nomination for his performance as we totally believe in every frame, every scene, and every moment that he is Desmond Doss. No other actor could have taken on the title role, as Garfield inhabits the character so much that at one point we no longer see Andrew Garfield. We see Desmond Doss. Garfield is so convincing as the character that he even nails the Doss's southern Virginian accent to a tee! We are definitely watching something epic from an actor who is just getting his feet wet in the business, and still hopefully has much more to come. Especially with Martin Scorsese's religious drama "Silence," which comes out later this year. But most of the credit without a doubt goes to Mel Gibson, as he definitely directed this movie with a passion and displayed the realism Steven Spielberg showed us in "Saving Private Ryan." Bullets are literally flying everywhere in the second half of the story where the war part takes place. You literally feel yourself cringing in your seat in the theaters as we men getting shot left and right in every direction to the point where you really start to feel that ANYBODY. Even the main cast could be struck or killed at any moment. That's the level of genius we are dealing with behind the camera. I still think "Braveheart" is Mel Gibson's masterpiece, but this is without a doubt a close second to other two films he directed before this such as "The Passion of the Christ," and of course "Apocalypto." Gibson does an absolute incredibly job at showing us the graphic horror of war and how scary it is for a young man serving his country to be in combat, especially fighting an enemy that doesn't believe in giving up. It goes without saying that the true story of Desmond Doss is incredible and inspiring on every level. I would recommend it 100% based on that alone. But Hacksaw Ridge is simply a textbook study of surehanded and meticulous filmmaking. Just as with his other films, Gibson shows an almost obsessive understanding of how to communicate a story using the human body. He paints stories with faces, eyes and hands in a way that few other directors do. His style is classical but surreal. The hills and mountains of Virginia are photographed  with as much surreal beauty as Middle Earth. The war scenes are nightmarish hellscapes filled with severed limbs and nonstop screaming. Anyone expecting thrills from the war scenes here will find something much closer to a horror film instead. Gibson paints a very unflattering picture of the battlefield, using a lot of the same tricks as Passion of the Christ; he lets us peer deep into the eyes of soldiers filled with violent hatred without pulling the camera away - a sight that is far more terrifying than the countless severed limbs and blood sprays that paint the screen red.

He even takes an unflinching look into the heart of the story's hero, Doss, suggesting that his hardlining pacifist stance is not due to moral superiority, but his way of combating his own deep-rooted capacity for horrible violence. This portrayal of Doss sees himself as a murderer waiting to happen, and looks to his Christian faith and a lifestyle of peacemaking to keep this horrible beast chained up.

There's a lot of other great stuff in the film as well; Doss is an example of someone whose refusal to compromise on his prinicpals is rewarded with persecution, isolation and physical pain. The film warns that convictions are costly, but the results speak for themselves. That's not to say it's preachy, though. So much of what makes Hacksaw Ridge profound and insightful is not what's written on the page but what is written on the actors' and extra's faces as this now legendary story plays out.

For me, this is not only my new favorite war film of all time, but probably my favorite film dealing with issues of faith and violence. It's certainly the best thing to come out of 2016 so far. If you can stomach the circus of horrors that awaits you in the 3rd act, I would strongly urge anyone and everyone to see it.

Putting aside his personal life, Mel Gibson is a great director & has a knack for big scope pictures based on true stories.  Now is Hacksaw Ridge the next great thing from the infamous director?  Maybe, maybe not.

As I say about a lot of genres these days, we don't get a lot of great war films.  We just don't.  Free State of Jones, Whiskey Tango Foxtrot, and even 13 Hours haven't been great.  But I was hoping Hacksaw Ridge would reinvigorate the genre, and perhaps reinvent it.  To a certain extent, it does.  A story about a Seventh-day Adventist who wants to join the army as a conscientious objector makes for a different way of telling a World War II story.

I think the problem here is that the first and second halves of this story feel like two completely different films altogether.  The first mainly deals with Desmond Doss' (Andrew Garfield) budding romance with Dorothy Schutte (Teresa Palmer) back at his hometown of Lynchburg, Virgina.  I really bought into the cuteness and sincerity of that relationship, but it gets lost entirely in the second half.   I think I would have preferred more of a balance between a straight romance story and a straight war film.  And not a split down the halfway mark of the film, I mean each aspect sprinkling into each other.

I can't deny how impressive Gibson's ability to direct intense battle sequences is, however.  Braveheart has one of the most beautifully shot finales of all time, and there's plenty of that to go around in the battle sequences here.  The fact that Doss' beliefs prevented him from being able to pick up any sort of weapon and he managed to save over 70 men during the Battle of Okinawa.  The story is remarkable and watching Doss relentlessly saving one person after another when everyone else had left, is definitely inspiring.  But I think the rush of it all overwhelmed my enjoyment of the battle, considering the first half is a different film entirely.

Vince Vaughn, Hugo Weaving, and Rachel Griffiths round out the cast nicely and add other levels of emotion to an already fascinating story.  But if I had to change something, it would be the pacing and direction from Gibson.  If Gibson could have found a way to sprinkle in romantic scenes to the unsettling battle or the other way around, the film would have been more fluid and even.  Other than that, this is definitely a film worth seeing in theaters just for the remarkable performance of Garfield alone.

Hacksaw Ridge is the masterful telling of a true story of a pacifist who saves 75 of his fellow soldiers in the battle of Okinawa without ever using a weapon. I uh, I left this movie speechless. It was so difficult to formulate my thoughts after a film like that and I didn't even know how to react. I was stunned. My breath was taken away. I was on the verge of tears. This is by far the best war film I've ever seen throughout my short-lived life. This was the most intense, one of the best written, and easily the most graphic war movie I've seen thus far. I even timed this perfectly with Veteran's Day, which I felt would be a great tribute to those who fought for our country. 

If we're to start somewhere, we'll start off with the violence of this movie. This is the most graphic and realistic depiction of a war battle that I've ever seen. "Lone Survivor" was gritty, "Fury" was gross, and "American Sniper" was emotionally draining, but "Hacksaw Ridge" takes all your favorite elements from those films and puts them into one. The minute bullets start flying, things get real ugly real fast. The depiction of war is extremely ugly and it is difficult to watch at times. This movie is not for the faint of heart and shouldn't be taken so, as it shows that war is ugly, and there's not a single pretty aspect about it. The movie is gory, bloody, and realistic, and I praise it for that. 

The performances in this movie were amazing. I've always loved Andrew Garfield, despite the flack he's gotten throughout his career. What I love most about him is his ability to bring out the personality of each character he plays, ranging from the little things to the big things. He makes his character unique and interesting and I think he pays such a great tribute to Doss. Doss was an odd and different man, but a noble one at that. I didn't realize that Teresa Palmer was in this film and although she didn't have a big part, she was fantastic. She stood out in the few scenes she was in and was a great compliment to Garfield. Sam Worthington also did so well and was better than most would've expected. But I think the biggest surprise in this movie was Vince Vaughn. I love seeing actors, especially comedic actors, take on a role that clearly strays form their norm. Vaughn's name hasn't been too hot the past few years, but his resurgence with this more serious role is a nice one. 

The screenplay was amazing. I genuinely loved this movie and everything about it. The dialogue could've had a few tweaks in it at times but even then, I felt it was handled really well. When you fact check this film, there are some pretty glaring plot holes. However, they're not plot holes that come off as disrespectful. Mel Gibson added some things into the story and changed somethings for the sake of cinema, which I actually felt added to the story. It made the story a little more clear and just that much more intense. It doesn't pay disrespect to the real life events, but it enhances the message behind them. 

The message and the overall meaning behind the true story is so amazing. It's honestly breathtaking and I am still so stunned. I still can't even formulate all my thoughts as I was literally blown away by this movie. This shows that war is ugly and the human race is ugly. But someone like Doss is so essential to this world. He provided this spark of hope that changed so much. Doss passed away years ago, and I wish I could've had the immense pleasure to meet him. This movie also greatly increased my respect for the military and what they go through.

In the end, this is one of the best war movies of the year. In fact, it's one of the best movies of the year. In fact, it's one of the best war movies I've ever seen. I loved this movie and if you really want a true cinematic experience and an amazing story, watch this film. I say again, this movie's not for the faint of heart, but it deserves to be seen. I only give a film 5 stars if it's truly had an impact on me somehow, and this movie clearly did just that.

This is a phenomenal movie. Say what you will about Mel Gibson as a person, but he is a magnificent director. He navigates this complex and difficult story with ease, knowing the perfect ratio of character-driven moments to war-filled madness. The different aesthetic choices he made, in terms of the tone of the film and his approach to the different aspects of the movie, continue to prove his ability as a director. I'll get more into the war scenes later, but the way he chooses to showcase these sequences is masterful. Sure, we get tons of gory and bloody violence, but never does it feel glorified or for entertainment. It is purely to show the horrors of war and the madness that ensues on the battlefield, and Gibson walked that line perfectly. He also does fantastic things with the character of Desmond Doss, and how he uses other people's reactions to him to tell Desmond's story for him. Gibson easily could have had Desmond give us long, exposition-filled speeches about why he chooses not to kill, and we do get a couple of those, but only when they are absolutely necessary. Instead, Gibson utilizes supporting characters and the environment to paint the picture of why Desmond won't kill. It's a perfect example of show not tell, and I think it ultimately shows Gibson's mastery as a director...

The film is based on the true story of Desmond Doss, a conscientious objector, who ended up saving the lives of 75 Americans in Okinawa during the bloodiest battle of WWII, without firing or carrying a gun. Andrew Garfield plays Doss with bold conviction cutting to the heart of the character.

Its second act takes us to the battlefield. Gibson does not shy away from the horrors of war and the violence that comes with it. As a director, this is where he is at his best - capturing the heroism and consternation of war.

"Hacksaw Ridge" is about selflessness and standing by your own convictions especially when faced with so much resistance from the other side. The story of Desmond Doss and his military service is heartening. And when we thought that the stories of WWII have all been told, another one comes along and surprises us capturing our hearts and minds.

It has been a decade since Mel Gibson directed his last film. Almost as much time as there was between Braveheart and Passion of the Christ, but in this latest interval Gibson has unfortunately become more discussed for things besides his filmmaking talents. With Hacksaw Ridge, the story of WWII American Army Medic Desmond T. Doss who refused to kill people as a Conscientious Objector, Gibson is very much back in the playing field he seems comfortable with. That said, Gibson seems to have also taken the time away to pull in other influences for his art as many of the early scenes here in which the director develops and builds the character of Doss with actor Andrew Garfield (The Social Network, The Amazing Spider-Man) feel as if they were constructed to be a love letter to Hollywood's golden years. This, of course, deeply contrasts the usually stark and brutal tone that Gibson's films take on, but don't fret as those qualities are sure to come still in Hacksaw Ridge. More, Gibson understands that by painting these early, more serene portraits of where his pacifist of a protagonist comes from he by default makes the bloody and downright horrific war sequences that inevitably take place that much more affecting and that much more powerful. Though somewhat working at odds with one another given how realistically and viscerally Gibson paints his scenes of war with a story that more or less condemns such actions these two elements of what we're seeing and what train of thought we're being encouraged to consider come to work in each other's favors. For as quickly as we see how easily a life can be snuffed out and how faithful Doss has to be to trust that he can "run into the hell fire of battle without a weapon to protect his self," and still survive the point is made that the violence of war is senseless and that, after such an experience, most soldiers would likely agree with such a sentiment. Gibson isn't just making a war film to show off how skilled an action director he is or to revel in the gluttony of violence, but more he is using this profusion of blood and gore to align us more with the mentality that Doss brings to the battlefield and why, despite popular opinion, that might not be such a bad thing. The greatest accomplishment of Hacksaw Ridge though, is that it accomplishes relaying such ideas without preaching them, but instead more by standing with its lead character who stands by his principles even in the great circumstances of a world war.
