It's been a while since we had an excellent war film right? Sure films like Fury, The Hurt Locker & American Sniper played their parts well in adding to the genre, but in comparison to the classics such as Apocalypse Now, Platoon or Saving Private Ryan, they fall short. Some war films use a particular war from history to tell a fictional story, all three of the above for example, however, a war film for me becomes something else entirely when it tells a true story, especially one as remarkable as the story that this film is based on. War films can be a bit hard to sit through, with its graphic depictions of key battles in history, strong themes of power, brotherhood and the effect it has among the world but with Mel Gibson's latest war drama it manages to be something more that we can grasp it. No matter what you think about Mel Gibson as a person, after watching this film you will agree that he has made his contribution in the form of one of the greatest war films. This is a remarkable film about a remarkable true story you can't believe actually happened. Based on the true story of US Army medic Desmond T. Doss, a man who refused to bear arms, yet was awarded the Medal of Honor by President Harry S. Truman for single-handedly saving the lives of over 75 of his comrades while under constant enemy fire during the Battle of Okinawa in World War II. If you've seen Braveheart  or the Passion of the Christ you know that Gibson is one of the few directors who have mastered the art of film making. If you want further proof than look no further, as this is another fine example of his work. The story follows Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield), a devout Christian and member of the Seventh-Day Adventist raised by his caring mother Bertha (Rachel Griffiths) and abusive alcohol father Tom (Hugo Weaving) strained by his experience in World War I. With World War II ravaging, Desmond enlists in the army as a Conscious Objector and to serve as a medic. During boot camp training, he faces causes displeasure in his drill sergeant Sgt Howell (Vince Vaughn) and commanding officer Captain Glover (Sam Worthington) when he refuses to touch a gun due to his religious beliefs. But when his platoon is deployed on the battlefield in Okinawa, Japan, Desmond proves to be more worthy as a soldier than many believe when saves over 50 wounded soldiers without even firing a single shot. Gibson returns to the director's chair to helm this true story, giving his touch of humanistic quality, anti-war themes and brutality to the horrors of war to much great detail. The direction is pretty much on point throughout and never goes dull or loses itself during its 131 minutes running time. One of the biggest ironies is how Mel Gibson cohesively makes a case of pacifism through an unflinchingly brutal portrayal of the horrors of war, and the story of how lead character Desmond Doss must face the violent nature of active combat that greatly conflicts with his religious beliefs. The first half of the film introduces Desmond as a young man who embraces his spirituality, while forced to deal with abusive upbringing by his father Tom who feels scarred by his son when he decides along his Howard (Desmond's brother) to enlist in the war, recounting his harrowing experience in World War I that cost the lives of his friends. Along the way, we are then introduced to hot-shot nurse Dorothy (Teresa Palmer) who Desmond quickly forms a relationship and provides some sweet moments of levity and connection for Desmond when he out overseas on the battlefields, though the depiction of their romance is a bit hokey and somewhat awkward during the first half-hour. Ultimately, the first hour is primarily about establishing Desmond's pacifism and the cruel nature in which he endures when he makes himself the center of ridicule by his officers and fellow comrades who view of his refusal of abandoning his firmly held conviction against fighting as an act of cowardly, which is gracefully brought together in the boot camp training sequences in the fashion of 'Full Metal Jacket'. It's only in the second half we get into depicting the Battle of Okinawa at Hacksaw Ridge, the site of one of the bravest human feats in history. Both tell the story of the determined individual that Doss was and Mel Gibson does a wonderful job in directing the film. Much of the film is steeped in realism, something that Mel Gibson specializes in when it comes to violence. While the story and plot line may sound very traditional, the way it is portrayed is a fresh burst of life into a tired genre such as this. That, coupled with the amazing true-life story of Desmond Doss being portrayed on screen, makes this film a wild and brutal trip down the path to religion and the power that faith can give a man. Gibson, a devout Catholic himself, would be the director to bring this story to life. His religious views seep through his very being, especially through his films and this film is no exception. The film settles in the idea that God is literally protecting Doss, not only physically but spiritually as well. Doss is constantly tested throughout the film, almost needing to take a life (which is the ultimate sin to him) in many scenes. The fact that this man did not fire a single round and saved as many men as he did is astounding and the film really does an amazing job at showing the harsh realities of war but also showing the good that can be brought out in a man through his faith. The film itself is one of Gibson's less preachy works which makes it more accessible. Even if faith-based films are not your thing, you can appreciate the craft that went into making this film. This is not just simply a war film, but a man's own personal war against the people and powers that be that tried to suppress him and his faith only to be proved wrong. This film is about as good as you can get these days and everything here is done to sheer perfection from the outstanding acting to the war scenes to the makeup, sets and everything done to capture not only the period elements of the time, but also to not only take us to those battle lines, but make us feel as if we were right there and experiencing them for ourselves. This film displays war as atrocious as it truly is. True to his reputation Mel does not hold back with the battle scenes. The devastation is already extensive and the ground strewn with bits of bodies by the time the 77th arrives. The battlefield scenes are the most harrowing I have ever seen. There is nothing left to the imagination with shock after visceral shock coming at you for a good twenty minutes. The effect is an adrenaline surge as you feel like you are trying to survive with Doss and the rest of his troop. The payoff occurs after Doss does what he does and comes off Hacksaw Ridge. It is so emotional. The effect is amazing and it is all steered by Gibson's intense direction. The shattering reality of war is dizzying and full of impact, moving so quickly you can barely identify the characters in a whirlwind of panic, pain and death. But amidst the chaos, Desmond Doss's character is revealed to everyone and even his harshest critics realize how wrong they were about him. Watching the story change from having the battalion hating him so much that they try to have him imprisoned, to refusing to go on the battlefield without him, is so moving and inspiring. Neither war itself nor violence is glorified in the film, yet they also not derided. The elements of conflict that draw the storyteller - the heroism of overcoming adversity, the bonding of soldiers, and the brave resolve on which soldiers must rely to perform their duty amidst such chaos and terror - these elements are all present, but they placed alongside the horror, the madness and the terror of war, and used to draw in the audience for Doss' journey. The lasting psychological impact for those who survive conflict is well told by Hugo Weaving's portrayal of Doss' father, whose lines could serve as a mouthpiece for many veterans. The heroism depicted in this story is of such an extraordinary magnitude that it can easily overwhelm any consideration of the film's merits. With an uncomplicated and factual narrative arc, the story rests on two pillars: acting and filming. On both scores, this film deserves high praise. The most outstanding element of this film, however, is its powerhouse hyper-realistic cinematography and spectacular set constructions that relentlessly convey the brutality of war. While it is an outstanding technical production, giving spectacle precedence over narrative is the film's Achilles Heel. One or maybe a few helmeted heads shredded or bodies bayoneted can convey much, but twenty deadens the senses. If ever there was a case where less could have been more, this is it. The score by Rupert Gregson-Williams is terrific, varying between nerve-wracking tones during the quiet pauses between battles, and then turning to a beautiful heroic melody for our main character. The whole film is carried by Andrew Garfield's performance and he doesn't disappoint, as he gives the best performance of his career here. He brings us a soft spoken, earnest and strong willed Desmond and the actor gives his all throughout the film, both emotionally and physically. Teresa Palmer has delightful chemistry with Garfield as his love interest and gives the courtship scenes a charming old-fashioned feel. We also get excellent performances from surprising supporting actors, such as Vince Vaughn. The usually comedic actor gives an effective dramatic performance as a drill instructor and infuses his witty humor during the boot camp scenes. Sam Worthington also gives a surprisingly good performance as Doss' cynical superior officer. Both these actors aren't specifically known for their acting prowess, but both do their characters justice in this film. Luke Bracey as Smitty Ryker also plays his part well. The standout supporting actor was Hugo Weaving, as Desmond's father who is a veteran-turned-angry drunk. Weaving gives the man an intense and vicious persona, and with little small tics, makes you believe the man has been through immense pain and loss. Mel Gibson has attracted a lot of bad press over the years but there is no denying that he is a good director, and here, he may just have made his best film yet. It's the emotional power of the story that Gibson taps into so successfully that makes this film one of the best of the year. On the whole, 'Hacksaw Ridge' is a brutally powerful emotional cinematic landmark that works due to its excellent storytelling, terrific acting performances, and marks a highly admirable directorial return for Mel Gibson. Must Watch!

After much internal debate, I finally decided to see Hacksaw Ridge.  It was as inspirational as it was gory.  In fact, it was even more inspirational than I hoped, and even more gory than I feared.  It is likely to make every Christian want to be as faithful as Desmond Doss, and be ashamed not to be. 
I was expecting the movie to be religious and violent-but I wasn't expecting it to remind me of what true patriotism is.  The movie is set during World War II, when the military wasn't crippled by political correctness.  Generals were ordered to fight to win-not fight to tie.  Every American knew who the enemy was, what it would take to defeat that enemy, and wanted to be part of the victory in whatever way possible.
 The battle scene at the end seemed to go on terribly long-longer than I wanted to watch.  But I could not help thinking that the real battle went on much longer, and was much worse than was shown on the screen.   The graphic violence was necessary to make the point.
I went at 1 PM in the afternoon, which probably explains why everyone in the theater looked to be older than 60.  Once the movie began, all the talking ended and the atmosphere became more reverent than many churches.  When the movie ended, everyone left quietly without saying a word.  Clearly everyone was moved; but I wondered what moved them the most.  Since nobody said a thing, I don't know how they were moved, and what lasting impression it made.  I wonder how a younger audience, largely ignorant of the horrors of World War II, would react to it.
It is an important movie that deserves an Academy Award; but, given the director and subject matter, it probably won't even get a nomination.

Mel Gibson needs to direct more movies. End of statement. It's been a decade since Gibson last helmed a movie, 2006's visceral art film for jocks, Apocalypto, and he's been in "movie jail" ever since a string of controversial drunken statements. His new movie is a completely earnest, classical example of storytelling that you just as easily could see faces of old appear (say John Wayne in place of curmudgeonly Vince Vaughn), and Hacksaw Ridge is a stirring war movie and a stirring character study. Andrew Garfield plays Desmond Doss, a conscientious objector who wanted to go to war but refused to touch a gun. The first half of the movie is the U.S. Army trying to make sense of this inherent conflict, looking for ways to intimidate him, make him compromise, or kick him out of service. Yet, he endures, and it's in the second half that Doss single-handedly saves 75 wounded men as a medic left alone on a deserted battlefield in the Pacific. Garfield (Amazing Spider-Man) is a solid lead performance, though his cornpone West Virginia accent irritated me... until the real Desmond Doss is showcased in archival footage and he sounds exactly alike. The supporting characters are rich and have more depth than I was expecting, including Hugo Weaving as Doss' father, a drunken shell from his WWI survivor's guilt. There's much more complexity to what otherwise could be a hateful drunk and one-note character foil. The one miss I felt was the courtship between Doss and his future wife (Teresa Palmer). It felt like an outdated perspective where a man's insistence overrode a woman's agency and he was rewarded for it. Admittedly, that's a modern perspective applied to a generational relationship from long ago. The movie is naturally graphic but the bloody violence is stylized in a way that communicates the ugliness and chaos of war. The action develops and is grisly and engaging without losing sense of the characters and without falling into redundancy. When Doss is rescuing survivors in the final act, the movie finds new challenges that he has to overcome to keep things interesting and raise the stakes. Gibson's images can be frightfully beautiful; his command of visual storytelling and its evocative power is too good for only one movie a decade. It may be impossible to make an anti-war movie without in some way glamorizing war, so even though Hacksaw Ridge celebrates the heroism of one man's anti-violence values it finds a mainstream sense of entertainment in the carnage. It's like a tentpole Oscar movie and I hope I don't have to wait until 2026 for the next Gibson-directed vehicle.

This film is not easy to watch as many of the graphically violent scenes may make you cringe, close your eyes, or turn away from the screen as I did. Although the number of war torn bodies in this film was far greater than what I saw in Vietnam, the point wasn't lost on me: "war is hell" as William T. Sherman in 1870 said and Director Mel Gibson wanted us to see. As he did in "Passion of the Christ" and "Apocalypto", Gibson shows us man's inhumanity to man.

Here he shows us Desmond Doss (Darcy Bryce and Andrew Garfield), whose belief in God, as a Seventh Day Adventist, won't allow him to take another man's life. We also see the lessons he learns from a difficult childhood. His father, Tom (Hugo Weaving), is an alcoholic which began with his own suffering from the loss of his childhood friends in WW I. The beatings his mother Bertha (Rachel Griffiths), brother Hal (Roman Guerriero and Nathaniel Buzolic) and he take, affected him deeply and as an audience member, were difficult to witness.

Because he has a sense of duty, despite the objections of his mother and father, he signs up to join the WWII effort as a medic Conscientious Objector in the US Army. Prior to his induction he meets Dorothy Schutte (Teresa Palmer) whom he charms with his wholesome, caring and kind nature. She sees the depth of his integrity and they agree to marry on his first leave.

When his platoon Sergeant Howell (Vince Vaughn) announces to the rest of his platoon that Desmond won't be carrying a gun to protect his peers, they make him a pariah. He's beaten and disowned by his fellow soldiers and they even try to Court Martial him out of the Army.

Gibson painstakingly develops the backstory so that when Desmond enters the battle for Hacksaw Ridge the audience is ready for him to become the hero he became. As the first of only three Conscientious Objectors to receive the Medal of Honor, Desmond amazes his fellow soldiers. Alone he saves 75 wounded men by saying to himself and to his God, "give me the strength to save just one more".

The battle itself is one of the most graphic you'll ever witness and it is important to know this going in. For me it triggered huge sadness because of the memory of piling up dead Viet Cong soldiers after an all-night firefight.

Although this film is long at 2 hours and 11 minutes, the elongated battle scenes are extremely well orchestrated giving the audience a sequence of stories all tying together.

Garfield was spectacular and amazing in this performance. His embodiment of Doss was deeply heartfelt. I would predict that he may receive an Oscar nomination, along with a real chance to win. I'd definitely give him a vote. Weaving was powerful as the father who was gutted by his involvement in WWI along with how this, and his alcoholism, affected his life. The last scene where he reaches out to help his son was deeply heartfelt. Vaughn was in the best non-comedic role I've ever seen him in. In my view, this role brought a new dimension to his acting abilities. Bryce and Guerrieo were wonderful as the young Doss brothers. Palmer was fantastic as Desmond's one true love. Griffiths was very good as Desmond's suffering and faithful mother. Andrew Knight and Robert Schenkkan wrote a fantastic screenplay. This screenplay is Oscar worthy and the dialogue is amazing in its range. It contained humor, military order and strictness, romanticism, and spiritual beliefs all wrapped into one film effectively. Gibson, regardless of how you may think of him as a celebrity and person, his direction of this film is truly amazing. Like Spielberg, he knows how to craft scenes of war in a way that can make an audience feel the experience. He deserves to be given consideration for an Oscar as well. If you see this film, make sure you watch the short clips during the credits of the real Desmond and others who knew him.

Overall: Although this film can be hard to watch at times, it clearly makes a strong point about the power of one man living his truth.

One of the most brutally visceral war movies I've ever seen. It's an interesting contrast to one of the most cloyingly naive war hero protagonists put on screen. In the end, these two paradoxical things come together pretty well into an interesting and very emotional story. It doesn't quite match the best movies in this deep genre, but it's definitely a worthwhile filmmaking effort from one of the great Directors alive today.

Initially, I was a bit disappointed with Andrew Garfield's performance as Private Desmond Doss, because he seemed too unrealistic in his innocent martyr/saint profile. But once he got onto the battlefield, he came more to life to me. It's almost like things got real for him (and me as a viewer). I was especially taken with his impactful sharing of his near shooting of his father for beating his mother with his enemy-turned-friend foxhole companion Smitty. It explained his internal motivations more, which I was struggling to connect to. Combined with his heroic "one more" saving lives sequence, I started to appreciate some authenticity in the Doss character. And that held up until the heavenly ascent of his character off Hacksaw Ridge and into the real life patriotic documentary tribute that Gibson ended the film with.

While I feel about mixed about the film overall, there's no denying that the filmmaking on this movie is top notch in every technical department, from the cinematography to the production design to the sound and music. Gibson clearly had a team of incredible professionals and artists behind the camera bringing this story to life. I think with a better script and and a more Braveheart-like (i.e. less approval-seeking or political-correctness skewed) Gibson in the Director's chair, this film might have elevated itself into the upper echelon of WWII movies.

I want to watch this film again in the context of a marathon of what I consider to be the best war movies to see how it compares in a more direct comparative analysis.

"Hacksaw Ridge" is a film I implore you to see, if you feel at all that you can handle it. War is Hell, and Gibson necessarily shows it all. But he also shows us the best of us, too, and for God's sake I think we all can stand to learn a lesson or two from it.

Mel Gibson's first directorial effort in 10 years is one of the best war movies in a while. Based on a true story about a man whose religious beliefs prevented him from ever holding or firing a weapon. Despite this, he saved 75 lives without ever firing a shot or killing anyone. Teresa Palmer, Hugo Weaving, Sam Worthington, Rachel Griffiths, and Luke Bracy also give excellent performances. The movie is a tale of two acts. The first hour is the story of Doss and his family growing up in Virginia. It shows Doss's life and falling in love. The second hour does a 180 and is set entirely in Okinawa. The unflinching and graphic violence Gibson shows juxtapose the humble first hour. I like how the movie shows us there were heroes without making it too heroic. There is nothing fun about war and Gibson is able to make us feel the dread and hopelessness of all of it. Some stories are so unbelievable that it can't be true. Desmond Doss's story is unbelievable because it was true.

I'll just say it: Mel Gibson (as a director, anyways) is back. For those who don't remember (and for those who have understandably chosen to forget) Mel put himself in the doghouse back in 2006. A notorious and highly publicized DUI, drunken anti-Semitic rants, disturbing misogynistic recordings leaked by an ex-lover and disastrously embarrassing interviews all but destroyed his career. 2016 has seen Mad Mel come roaring back though with "Blood Father" being his first starring role in years, and now, his welcome return to the director's chair with "Hacksaw Ridge". The undeniably fearless actor-turned-filmmaker who brought us Braveheart and Apocalypto has come back with one of the best WWII films ever made. A heartfelt (and somehow true) story of Private Desmond Doss, a conscientious war objector presented with a Medal of Honor without so much as firing a gun. As a weaponless medic, he managed to save roughly 75 of his fellow soldiers during the battle of Okinawa. On paper, this sounds like an obvious attempt by Gibson to win back the audience he lost with melodramatic over-sentimentality, but it doesn't play that way. The war scenes are as brutal and bloody as they come. Anyone that sat through Braveheart's legendary savagery should easily be able to digest this though. As graphic as the these sequences get, it's tempered by so much humanity and heart that it's nearly impossible to get bogged down by it. The reason this whole thing goes down so well isn't really by Gibson's hand at all (although he certainly shows that his visionary chops have gone nowhere). The reason is Andrew Garfield. He delivers what has now become my favorite performance from a male actor that I've seen all year. His take on Private Doss is a wonder. He is simple, yet charming. Heroic, yet soft. Humane, yet ferocious....I honestly don't know where to even start. Whatever promise he showed as Spider-Man (and 2010's The Social Network, for that matter) was in no way adequate preparation for the gusto he brings here. The Oscar buzz couldn't be more appropriate. He deserves to be nominated and he deserves to win. Regardless, this is certainly a movie-lover's movie and should be seen in the theater for the proper affect. Possibly the best film of 2016.

It has been ten years since Mel Gibson was calling the shots for Mayan saga Apocalypto, but his direction here is so confident and ambitious you wouldn't know it. It's like he never left. This true story is essentially split into three parts: the introductory story to our heroic protagonist, the training segment full of adversity, and the horrific battle between the Yanks and the Japanese atop the eponymous ridge. Each act is better than the last, with the family and romantic drama at the beginning slow and not totally convincing, the boot camp section predictable but highly engaging, and the extended war climax an immersive triumph. It doesn't come as a surprise that Gibbo feels most comfortable with the battle scenes-he is the director of Braveheart after all-and in this respect he is firing on all cylinders, creating a truly intense and visceral experience. The death and decay is gruesome and unsettling-you can almost smell the burning flesh and rotting corpses-but the savagery is necessary to generate the authentic juxtaposition of horror and heroism. Portraying Desmond Doss, the first conscientious objector to win the Medal of Honor, Andrew Garfield is put the through the wringer both physically and emotionally, ultimately giving a solid performance despite working with some cheesy melodrama at the start. The supporting cast are predominantly strong, particularly Hugo Weaving who acts the hell out of his drunken WWI vet and Vince Vaughn who dishes out a delightfully shouty and zinger-filled turn as Doss' drill sergeant. A moving tale of one man's struggle to stay true to his beliefs whilst helping his country in the most harrowing of circumstances, Hacksaw Ridge is proof that Gibson should be behind the camera more often.

There is a dialectic to Mel Gibson's newest movie that does not entirely untangle itself through the course of the picture; though watching the tensions unfold is fascinating none-the-less. What I mean, particularly, is that HACKSAW RIDGE is a movie about a person who advocates for peace even though the picture itself is preoccupied with extremely graphic violence. Gibson, himself, describes HACKSAW RIDGE as an anti-war movie, even though it revels - often unnecessarily - in gore and mayhem. There may be something to be said about a "scare factor" - the idea that showing graphic violence will be horrifying and off-putting - even though such interest in horror risks satisfying an unhealthy voyeuristic revelry which might work to undermine Gibson's proclaimed cause. Although, to the contrary of the visual content, the explicit language of the characters acts as an antithesis to typical justifications of war at the expense of the values of those protest war. 
To provide some additional context, HACKSAW RIDGE is based (with seemingly excellent historical detail) on the life of Desmond Doss. Doss, played earnestly by Andrew Garfield, experienced a great deal of violence from his family as he was growing up and, ultimately, decided to turn his life around by swearing off the use of weapons. As an adult, Doss felt obligated to assist in defeating the axis powers during World War II. His family, especially his damaged father (portrayed with great nuance by Hugo Weaving) pressures Desmond to avoid participating in the war. Desmond succeeds at this restraint for a while, especially when he falls in love with a local nurse (played by Teresa Palmer, who is great in the role despite it being terribly underwritten). Eventually, Desmond can take no more and joins the military. The story continues to reveal the challenges that Doss had to overcome in order to maintain his beliefs regarding anti-violence while still participating in the war. 
We might note that Doss claimed to be a "conscientious cooperator" as a variation of "conscientious objector"... Doss, himself, desiring to actively contribute to a war effort while maintaining an anti-violent position provided an inherent contradiction that the movie struggled with adapted. I must admit, though, that contradictions are often intriguing - and this particular dialectic may have some productive possibilities bound up in it by being a catalyst for dialogue between those who disagree about the [lack of] value of carnal warfare. 
The movie feels very compelling, which is no doubt a testament to both the true-life story the movie is based on as well as the excellent production quality of the film. Virtually all of the technical elements are executed with precision and beauty. Additionally, the ensemble cast each showed thoroughly unique physical and vocal characterizations as well as emotional arcs. The whole movie has heart. Gibson's direction is no doubt a factor in the sheer energy and emotional grounding of the movie. I would imagine that most audience members would a difficult time being bored during this film - there are all sorts of interesting concepts to latch on to and they are virtually all presented in entertaining ways. I could go on about the virtues of the production aspects of the picture for some time. 
Ultimately, even though the movie may stumble in areas, it is seers with intrigue. And, I might add that I agree with the conclusion of the film, which reflects an attitude so eloquently explicated in the rising action of the movie by the protagonist: With the world set on tearing itself apart, it don't seem like such a bad thing to me to put a little bit of it back together.

Hacksaw Ridge is directed by Mel Gibson and stars Andrew Garfield as Desmond Doss, the first conscientious objector to receive the Medal of Honor for carrying 75 men to safety during World War II.

This movie was highly anticipated for me, and it didn't let me down. Gibson's effectiveness as a director is as strong as ever, especially during the brutal battle scenes. I'm usually indifferent when it comes to Andrew Garfield, but he disappeared into this character. The writing really fleshed out who Doss was and why he believed the things he did. He definitely had a strong supporting cast around him, too. Vince Vaughn continues to impress me with his dramatic chops, taking on the role of Doss' Sergeant. The standout supporting character was Doss' father, played by Hugo Weaving. Teresa Palmer continues to have a good year (Lights Out) portraying Doss' love interest. The film score accompanied this film perfectly, heightening the drama appropriately.

I don't really have a negative thing to say about this movie. Maybe it was exaggerated a bit for film's sake, but nothing ridiculous or unbelievable happened. Honestly, after sitting on this and really thinking, I have to put Hacksaw Ridge up there with Glory as one of my favorite war films. If you love inspirational movies like this, Hacksaw Ridge is an absolute must-see!

Final grade: A+

Have you ever been misunderstood? Maybe you just failed to communicate your thoughts effectively. Maybe you said or did something that cast doubt on your true intentions. Or maybe others just ascribed to you negative motives of people they've known in the past - and failed to judge you based on your own actions. We've all been there, but few of us have had to risk as much for our convictions as World War II Army medic Desmond T. Doss. You see, as a Seventh-day Adventist, Doss took the Bible literally. To him, the sixth commandment means God forbids killing anyone - ever - for any reason - even in war. He volunteered to be a medic in the war, but even in basic training, he steadfastly refused to even touch a gun. The law calls someone like Doss a conscientious objector. His fellow soldiers just called him a coward. That is... until they went into battle with him. Desmond's struggle to live out his principles, in spite of what others thought, and through the horrors of war, is the story of "Hacksaw Ridge" (R, 2:11).

As a child, Desmond (Darcy Bryce) developed a strong religious faith - and a strong aversion to violence. He and his brother physically fought each other often. One of those times, Desmond hit his brother with a brick, nearly killing him. Desmond's father, Tom (Hugo Weaving) used to beat his boys, and sometimes got physical with their mother, Bertha (Rachel Griffiths). Tom himself was a shell of a man who never shook memories of the violence he saw as a soldier in World War I, constantly visiting the graves of his friends who died in that war. All of this had a profound effect on Desmond in his formative years.

The adult Desmond (Golden Globe nominee Andrew Garfield) not only wants to avoid doing what he believes God prohibits, but he wants to do good things to help others. After saving the life of an accident victim by applying a tourniquet - and meeting a pretty local nurse named Dorothy (Teresa Palmer) - he develops a strong desire to study medicine. Even as he courts Dorothy, he feels drawn to do his part in the war - as an Army medic. As he says when defending his belief in non-violence, "With the world so set on tearing itself apart, it don't seem like such a bad thing to me to put a little bit of it back together."

Desmond may avoid violence, but violence sure finds him - and sooner than he expected. His drill instructor, Sgt. Howell (Vince Vaughn), and his company commander, Cpt. Glover (Sam Worthington), greet Desmond's convictions with frustration. His fellow trainees, especially people like Smitty Ryker (Luke Bracey), express their feelings towards him by attacking him in the barracks. When Cpt. Glover's boss, Col. Stelzer (Richard Roxburgh) gives Desmond a direct order to pick up a weapon and he refuses, the young recruit finds himself facing the possibility of an Army court martial - and maybe prison time.

Eventually, Cpl. Desmond Doss and his company find themselves arriving on the Japanese island of Okinawa in the closing months of the war. Now less than 400 miles from mainland Japan, the U.S. Army and Marine Corps experienced some of the fiercest fighting of the war - with some of the highest casualty rates. Doss' company is tasked with driving the Japanese soldiers off of Hacksaw Ridge - an area of land 400 feet above the beach. To accomplish their mission, the troops had to climb up a rocky cliff face using only a rope ladder - and then face well-entrenched Japanese forces which had vowed to fight to the death. Doss and his company charge straight toward danger. Not everyone would survive, but those who did, were Doss' responsibility - a mission for which he repeatedly put his life on the line.

I often find reviewers' comments in a movie's advertising to be overblown... but not in this case. "Hacksaw Ridge" IS one of the best war films since "Saving Private Ryan". The battle scenes in this film are even more graphic and intense than the scenes of D-Day in "Ryan", and features the most realistic Pacific Theater action since 2006's "Flags of Our Fathers". But like those other two, this film is more a story about the men who fought the war than the battles themselves. This is a bio-pic, so there's plenty of character development. It's a story about principles and courage, so there's plenty of struggle and heroism. And, as I said in my first paragraph, this is a story about misperceptions and, in the end, understanding and mutual respect, which contains lessons for all of us. This is a touching human story and an unflinching look at the horrors of war and the value of different kinds of heroism. "A"

Upon viewing the trailer, I was sure that Andrew Garfield could pull off an excellent Forrest Gump impression, and he did! Luckily, this film was so much more than just a weird cash grab for Mel Gibson. As usual for a Gibson film, there is tastefully choreographed ultraviolence mixed with exploitative emotional scripting. In this instance, it works out much better than "The Passion of the Christ". If you weren't paying attention, this movie might not seem exploitative at all. In fact, if you are Christian, you will probably think this is the best war film since "Saving Private Ryan". There is a protagonist who refuses to concede his faith for the sake of military protocol. He finds the strength within himself to accomplish a nearly impossible task...thanks to God. Then there are unrelenting violent shots of viscera, blood, and flying body parts. Fortunately, this film has much more to offer in terms of depth. As war films usually go, many seek to affirm the means of violence and destruction as somehow justifying the ends by creating heroes out of those conscripted to murder in the name of ideology. However, in this movie, the focus of heroism lies not in those who blindly follow orders and get blown to bits, but the man who demands that his ideology take precedence over an unquestioning, violent movement. In the end, both historically and fictionally, he is vindicated by his will and his actions. Sure, there are plenty of hackneyed war tropes going on here, but philosophically speaking, this is a sound and moral film. And I dare you not to tear up at some of Hugo Weaving's scenes. All in all, I think Zemeckis and Spielberg might be getting their jimmies rustled over the fact that a vocal anti-Semite might possibly out-epic them. But, then again, they didn't try very hard this year either.

The biggest challenge facing Hacksaw Ridge isn't the subject matter or it's extremely religious content. It's the man behind the camera. If you look at the film's poster, you'll quickly notice that the studio claims it's from "The acclaimed director of Braveheart and The Passion of the Christ" They're hoping that you forget the fact the Mel Gibson is behind all three of these movies. He is on the roster of celebrities whose personal life affects how their art is received. If you can put his horrible verbal tirades to the side, Hacksaw Ridge is worth taking in. Andrew Garfield leads the cast as Desmond Doss. He's a peaceful, happy-go-lucky young man despite his surroundings. His father, Tom (Weaving), is a violent alcoholic stemming from his days in combat during World War I. His mother (Griffiths) tries to hold the family together for Desmond and his brother, Harold (Buzolic). Desmond flirts his way into a first date with Army nurse Dorothy Shutte (Palmer). He's extremely rusty but his charm wins her over. Their budding relationship is tested when he decides to enlist to serve in World War II. Harold had already mentioned that he was going to serve his country, and now Desmond's announcement rocks his family.

Desmond is the ultimate optimist and is full of strong will. He's a Seventh Day Adventist, and due to the extreme devotion to his faith, he makes it very clear on his first day at boot camp that he refuses to touch a gun. He plans on being a medic, not someone looking to kill our enemies. It's a baffling concept for his fellow soldiers, but especially for drill Sergeant Howell (Vaughn). He is persecuted for his beliefs to the point where Captain Glover (Worthington) attempts to get him discharged for not following protocol. Desmond ultimately stays on and joins his fellow soldiers at Hacksaw Ridge in the Battle of Okinawa. He held strong onto his faith and his contributions would go on to win him the Medal of Honor from President Truman.

If you haven't already guessed by the subject matter, Hacksaw Ridge will be a very divisive film for many reasons. I mentioned Gibson's personal life earlier and many people will no doubt boycott the film as a way of boycotting what he has done in his past. I do find it odd knowing the words and slurs Gibson has thrown around to go ahead and be known for making two extremely religious films. There's a contradiction here that I can't help but take note of for someone of his specific beliefs. The film's core subject is all about Desmond's strong belief system. Faith-based films have been growing in Hollywood lately with the release of movies like Heaven is For Real, God's Not Dead, and Miracle from Heaven. Hacksaw Ridge takes a very different approach, as it isn't focused on a current day miracle or some wonder kid changing the town's view on God. Despite Hacksaw's strong and blatant message, it doesn't feel as gimmicky as some of those others. On the other hand, there will be audience members who will no doubt be turned off by the talk of God and the continual prayer and faith Desmond has to keep him going to save his soldiers in combat.

As a director, Mel Gibson is back to what he does best as he has not only starred in war films (We Were Soldiers, The Patriot), but he has also gone on to win two Oscars for Braveheart. There is a brutally honest aspect about Gibson that shows he isn't willing to downplay the horrors of what our soldiers went through. Gibson and cinematographer Simon Duggan put the audience in the thick of the action in a way that hasn't happened since Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan. If you ever thought Hollywood glamorized or softened the blow of what happens to our soldiers, this will open your eyes to the relentless and all-too real situations at hand. There are repeated moments where they show dismembered limbs, blown off bodies, and bullets ripping through the men at high speeds. There is one scene where a soldier takes a blown off torso and uses it as a shield to gain further ground. The blood usage should be noted for any audience member with a queasy stomach. Many veterans have said that Saving Private Ryan was too hard for them to watch. I assume Hacksaw Ridge will have same effect.

Andrew Garfield (The Amazing Spider-Man) gives another an admirable performance. He's going into the fall movie season with two strong contenders with this film and the new Martin Scorsese film, Silence. He has the noble determination as Desmond the soldier. He also has the charm needed in the first section of the film, as he's just so plucky in his attempt at wooing Teresa Palmer as the nurse. There's wonderful chemistry between them, which was lacking in Palmer's film The Choice that came out earlier this year. Having this part of the story open the film makes it all the more heartbreaking when he abruptly leaves to enlist. Gibson also gets a surprise turn from Vince Vaughn. I did a double take when he pops up as Doss's strict drill sergeant. He is by no means playing it Full Metal Jacket style, but it's a good dramatic role for him while allowing us to laugh at some of his outrageous commentary toward the other soldiers.

The film is the perfect material for someone like Gibson to make his entry back into Hollywood with the hope that moviegoers can focus in on the story. He pulls no punches in how graphic he allows the film to get, but that's the truth behind World War II. He brings out a different viewpoint on how we think of soldiers. In some war films, soldiers are thought of as killing machines who get a high out of taking down our enemy. Desmond Doss is the opposite. He had great strength, determination, and faith to help his country outside of picking up a rifle. It's an inspirational epic that reminds us of what many of our grandparents went through who served in WWII. Hacksaw Ridge is very much a religious film. If that doesn't bother you, it will no doubt be a powerful and moving piece and great reminder of the films Mel Gibson can make.

'Hacksaw Ridge' is a phenomenal War Drama/Biopic packed full with brutal, gritty action, amazing dramatic performances, and is headlined by an incredible return to the directors seat for visionary director Mel Gibson who absolutely kills in with this film. The film highlights the incredible story of Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield) who during WWII was the only US Soldier to fight the war without a firearm and managed to save the lives of 75 men with a huge amount of courage and determination. It's great to see yet another Australian film become so successful and get the worldwide appeal so many others do. 

Firstly, Andrew Garfield proves here once again that he is an immensely talented dramatic actor with by far one of if not the greatest performance of his career. The commitment on his part to sell this character to us and have us buy into his very distinct beliefs and motivations was fantastically done on his part. He does a great job to get you on board with his character so when he is dropped in the middle of a warzone the tension is heightened as you care for this character so much. His performance was so powerful that depending on the competition later in the year he could very well be in contention for a Best Actor nomination. The only thing in this film potentially hindering his chances of being recognised is not at all a bad thing. It is just that the almost just as strong performances put in by the supporting cast could steal some of the limelight from Garfield. Vince Vaughn does an exceptional job as Sgt. Howell in a role much more dramatic than we are used to seeing, and he also injects a small amount of humour in there that didn't feel jarring at all. 

Sam Worthington, Hugo Weaving, Teresa Palmer, and even Luke Bracey had very strong presences in this film and delivered performances that left no gaps in this film. Hugo Weaving specifically had some riveting scenes as the father Desmond Doss and really does completely steal the scenes he features in as his talents trump those of all other actors in the film. Every line of dialogue was delivered with so much conviction that you completely buy into the authenticity of the story and the interactions on show here. 

But there is no doubting that the real superstar of this film is none other than Mel Gibson who comes back after 10 long years to produce another phenomenal film up there with 'Passion of the Christ' and 'Braveheart'. He has come back bigger than ever proving that he still has what it takes to direct incredible and intense action sequences and also direct amazing character centric, dramatic, and emotional content better than most directors today. The way he films the war sequences here is absolutely stunning, they are intense and chaotic and you are literally holding your breath every second as he does not hold back on the violence and graphic nature making it all seem strikingly authentic. But these sequences would not have been nearly as shocking and effective if he hadn't set up every character as well as he did in the first half or more of the film. He utilises every minute of the film about as effectively as you can and gives every character so much personality and develops them enough to where you care for every single person that goes into battle. 

The only issue i had with this film is the very end, if this film was even 2 minutes longer i think it could have been tied up a little better but other than that this was exceptional. Seriously though, what better way to return to directing than with an Oscar nomination, because if he doesn't get a nominations for his achievements with this film then no-one will. That is of course if the Academy can look past the drama surrounding his past and just focus on the masterful piece of art he has created. And just a note, don't go into this film expecting a start to finish war, as the majority of this film takes a very character centric approach so that when the war scenes do come, they are so intense it feels like they last for 2 hours alone. 

So in the end this is another incredible directing job by Mel Gibson with phenomenal performances all round, and one of the best war dramas of recent years. Definitely one to check out for Mel Gibson, and for Australian Film in general.

I'm stealing this from my favorite reviewer because I think it sums up this film perfectly..."The opening thirty minutes charts Doss's pre-war life, from formative childhood events to the romance-portrayed, at times, in rather corny fashion-between Doss and his would-be wife, Dorothy (Teresa Palmer). The narrative is safe, both in structure and tone, and the boot camp section that follows has stock genre clichés (albeit very entertaining ones) led by Vince Vaughn's drill sergeant and his colorfully creative profanities, nicknames, and insults.

In short, "Hacksaw Ridge" is Mel Gibson's softest hour of filmmaking followed up by his hardest.

Indeed, when the explicit combat begins, the familiar conventional build-up-which appeared to lack sophistication-suddenly seems intentional by design. Having lulled us into a palatable, accessible formula, Gibson suddenly thrusts us into the vile gore of war. The leap is jarring, and makes the war scenes even more grotesque and repulsive by contrast."

Set aside your opinions of Mel Gibson and really take this movie in. Gibson can still direct the sh**t out of a movie. Hacksaw Ridge (2016) is his first film directed in ten years since Apocalypto (2006). The movie is about an army medic named Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield) who is a conscientious objector meaning he doesn't carry a gun and doesn't kill. We follow his early life and some events that lead him to become the man he becomes. Seeing his father Tom (Hugo Weaving) become a drunk and abuse his kids and wife because of WWI scars a young Desmond leading him to follow a much more religious path. Soon enough WWII breaks out and Desmond finds himself joining up much to the behest of his parents and girlfriend Dorothy (Teresa Palmer). Desmond has a hard time explaining to his drill sergeant Sergeant Howell (Vince Vaughn) exactly what a conscientious objector is and how he is still as reliable as any other man. The movie explores his journey through getting approval for his opinions about the war to his heroics in the battle of Okinawa. It's well acted and the cinematography is wonderful. Its a great story about a young man that stuck to his believes even if it meant getting beat by fellow soldiers, put on trial and ultimately almost losing his own life. One small gripe is the first hour does gloss a bit on events leading up to boot camp. Desmond seems to just kind of jump on the whole "I'm enrolling" bit and it would have been slightly nicer to develop him right before other than just seeing flashbacks, but the last hour more than enough makes up for it. The film is bloody and violent, but is a fantastic watch that I highly recommend taking a look at this weekend!

I was lucky enough to catch an early screening of Hacksaw Ridge last night. But I'd heard the buzz, and the trailer looked promising.

Andrew Garfield sold his sermon and I bought religion. From his pragmatic but prudent advances toward his love interest played by Teresa Palmer (who also owned it), to his religious defiance to bear arms, Andy kills it figuratively and.... well, that's about the only way he kills it.

But the real genius here is Mel Gibson who weaves you in and out of a love story peppered with corny comedy and fire and brimstone graphic violence like he's Dave Mustaine in a Megadeath ballet. Yes, this flick is gory to the mad max, but the graphic violence is imperative to put a fine point on the sheer size of this conscientious objector's cojones. At 2 hrs and 19 mins, the film paces out nicely with a heart-felt first half that sets a stark contrast against the second half of the film. Sincere, inspired and at times deeply disturbing, Hacksaw Ridge is one of those films that makes you want to be a better man.

Plain and simple, Hacksaw Ridge punched me right in my soul. This is the story of Desmond Doss, a soldier who wished to serve his country as a combat medic but refused to use a gun for religious reasons. It sounds crazy, as his superior officers and fellow soldiers are more than happy to inform him, but Desmond stands firm in his beliefs. His beliefs as a Seventh-day Adventist essentially throw him at the mercy of his comrades and his Sergeant, who was specifically ordered to give Desmond hell during basic training. But the story isn't just about people mocking Desmond for what he believes in and he just serves them humble pie in the end. This story is about men who are avowed in their hatred for Desmond, and Desmond responds by saving their lives.


	War is hell and this movie is not afraid of showing that. The movie itself only has two major battle scenes, both of which take place on the titular Hacksaw Ridge. These two battle scenes are some of the most gruesome I've ever seen, even more so than 2014's Fury. Constant shots of soldiers being lit on fire, blown to pieces by mortars and ripped to shreds by turret guns. They aren't quick camera cuts either; you see the soldiers roll around, screaming in agony as their flesh burns. When a mortar lands at the feet of a hapless soldier, you watch his limbs fly in every direction. I've never been truly bothered by gore but some of these scenes are genuinely hard to watch and honestly, the movie is better for that. It reminded me of why I know I'll never make it as a soldier which, in turn, makes me even more grateful for the men and women who are soldiers today. 


	I'll be completely honest, Andrew Garfield's portrayal of Doss was a little uncomfortable for me. Don't get me wrong, his acting was very good, way up from his Amazing Spiderman days but the way he would cover his teeth with his lips while talking in that exaggerated southern accent made it challenging to take him seriously. Now this is a nitpick, through and through. Like I said, Garfield's acting was fine and as far as I know, Doss may have really talked like this. When I researched the true story after watching the movie to fact-check, no source I found would touch on that. There's solid acting from all the other cast members as well.

	Hacksaw Ridge is a must-see regardless of your views of religion. The story of a lone man standing by what he believes in despite opposition and impossible odds is a story worth experiencing by everyone. I'm certain that a few people are gonna come out the woodwork claiming that the film is "too preachy" instead of, you know, the genuine thoughts going through Doss's head at the time but to those who can be mature about this and enjoy the movie for what it is, you will not be disappointed.

The movie, on the other hand, fails to do his story justice and is absolutely DOOMED by terrible casting, poor acting, and an apparent complete lack of any kind of military advisor on set.

The main character was cast well.  His father, a WW I vet, is Agent Smith from The Matrix.  However I thought he did a good job as well.  Doss' wife and mother were also good. For me, a promising film just fell apart when Doss enlists. 

Vince "If You Can Dodge a Wrench You Can Dodge a Ball" Vaughn is unbelievably cast as Private Doss' drill sergeant.  There is a stereotypical supporting cast of what I can only assume are off-Broadway, C-list actors as the other soldiers as I didn't recognize anyone (which is fine) but who kind of suck at the whole acting thing. 'Hacksaw Ridge' (sounds like a good horror movie!) is a World War II film that does an admirable job of spending almost half the film in America, before they even ship off to Japan to fight. This gives us plenty of time to meet Desmond Doss (Garfield) and his family and find out how/why he ticks. He decides he can't sit by why others go off to defend America, but he also conscientiously objects to killing another human, so can't use any weapons. Big moral dilemma and the film deals with it well. It also gives us time to care about some of the other characters in the unit, so we know who's who when the fighting starts.

It's kind of amazing Mel Gibson has only directed five films, considering two of them (Braveheart' and 'Apocalypto') are classics - with this film soon to join them. He could turn into the next Eastwood... He also knows his way around a war film, having been in 'Gallipoli', 'Air America' and 'We Were Soldiers', so it's no surprise 'Hacksaw Ridge' is handled expertly. It's nice to see him populate the film with quality Australian actors (it was filmed in Sydney) - Weaving as Doss' dad, Griffiths as his mum, Worthington as his Captain, Palmer as his girlfriend, Nable as a Lieutenant, Bracey as his nemesis and Roxburgh as the Colonel.

When they do arrive at Okinawa, Japan, obviously all hells breaks loose, with some great shots of the artillery explosions, then the chaos of bullets, grenades and blood - certainly no punches pulled when it comes to the body count or the gore shown. The scenes with Doss rescuing dozens of his injured comrades from the battlefield are astounding. Garfield really shines as Doss and it hits home how much of a hero he was - highlighting that there's always room for some good in the harsh world.

Overall: Excellent and unique the war film

"While everybody is taking life I'm going to be saving it" - the words declared by the medic, Desmond Doss, the hero of "Hacksaw Ridge". His story is the authentic one. Doss joined the army in 1942 after the attack on Pearl Harbor. During his service, he refused to carry a weapon and kill enemies, justifying his decision based on religious beliefs. Despite all the objection, he saved the lives of 75 soldiers in the bloody Battle of Okinawa. For his heroic actions, Desmond recieved America's highest military commendation, the Medal of Honor.

Doss's biography is a dream material for a film. There is a place for the military spectacle, romance, family drama and friendship, forged in the fires of rifles and mortars. Mel Gibson, who is comfortable in epic narratives, has much to offer. It is to be hoped that Hollywood forgets his excesses and doesn't omit "Hacksaw Ridge" in the upcoming awards season.

Gibson's film has an articulate three-act structure. First act depicts our hero's childhood and adolescence spent in Virginia. An essential figure in this chapter is Desmond's father - I Wolrd War veteran who battles the traumatic memories, from the front, with the help of whiskey. The alarming questions is: Is Desmond going to meet the same fate?

Second act - military training in boot camp - the moment in which Doss confronts his ideals with reality. He has to prove that he's neither a coward nor a madman. That the courage not always goes with using physical strenght. This part of the film is filled with sublime scenes. Actors help the director achieve this effect. Vince Vaughn has a fine performance as a strict sergeant. Hugo Weaving is authentic, in the role of an alcoholic father. Similarly, Terasa Palmer proves well as a love interest of our hero. However, the loudest applause goes to Andrew Garfield. As Desmond, he gets through to the audience.

The last stage of the film is an ongoing, impressive battle sequence. Since "Saving Private Ryan" there hasn't been an equally brutal  military scene. The camera doesn't save the audience from the sight of exploading  bodies, torn off limbs and intestines lying on the ground. The most emotional part of "Hacksaw Ridge" starts when the war dust falls and the main character faces the bloody conflagration.

In this engaging story of heroism, the clash point is religion. Ignore the fact that to honour our objector, Gibson had to organise a festival of death on the screen. It is hard to believe in the massage of peace and charity since the thing that satisfies the director the most is the view of killing soldiers. This way or another: it is a great film.

Hacksaw Ridge is a graphic, heart wrenching and compelling story that follows Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield) who grows up in a household where his father served in the war and came back changed. He is more aggressive, more heartless, shows signs of losing his mind and at times shows that he wants to end it all. Desmond sees the pain in his father and what violence does to people and decides like his brother to join the military to fight for  his country but to do it a different way. Desmond however has a particular resolve and wants to enter the military as a medic and not carry any weapons to battle. Once he is placed with his company he finds the army has made the mistake of putting him with a rifle group. Despite completing every task he has been given besides handling a rifle, he goes through all kinds of attempts to make him lose his resolve or to just quit. He finally gets his time in court where it is declared that he has the right to fight in battle without any weapons.

This was a very powerful movie that will definitely tug at your heart and make you appreciate every man and woman that has served and is serving our country. Andrew Garfield does an immaculate job of portraying Desmond Doss. From the humble expressions, to the zeal and dedication to saving lives on the battlefield, Andrew was spot on. Mel Gibson has done it again by giving us a graphic yet heartwarming story. The production value was unrivaled. It truly displayed the very chaos that is seen on the battlefield and how you don't know when or where you will get shot, blown up, burned, stabbed or wounded in some way. It showed in great detail bodies getting blown in half, headshots, decapitations and just the plain ole blood and gore of war. Teresa Palmer is always a treasure to see and delivers yet again as she plays Desmond's love interest. Hugo showed me something I've never seen from him and that is he can emote very well. He played the drunkard, war scarred father with no problem and was believable every step of the way. Vince Vaughn was just hilarious playing the insulting bigoted drill sergeant. The things he said was just off the wall and placed a good bit of humor and a bit of accuracy of how old school drill sergeants were back then. This movie will leave an impression on you and it is a good one. If you liked Saving Private Ryan then you will definitely love this movie. The score, setting, acting and tone of the movie makes this easily a must see movie for adults.

Hacksaw Ridge is a gritty cinematic war film showing the violent events of it and Desmond Doss's religious courage. Even more so, when Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield) is true to his faith and vows to never bear arms and kill another, even in combat. He joins the military to serve as a medic and to help and save others during combat. Director Mel Gibson may not be likable to others, but when it comes to cinematic filmmaking, he can make a very strong theme about philosophies and the nasty side of war. His previous work like The Passion of the Christ and Apocalypto were both strong movies and can be brutal when it comes to violence. Hacksaw Ridge does not hold back, showing the intensity horrifying perspectives of war. Some may compare the cinematic violent nature to Saving Private Ryan. The battle sequences were gory, intense, and yet emotional to these men that were there. 

 The film follows Desmond, who lives with his religious mother Bertha and a drunken father Tom (Hugo Weaving) that struggles with post war after losing his friends. Desmond enlists in the army, in order to be a medic and to help save others. One condition that conflicts with him and his squad, he cannot bear arms or kill another. Which causes his Sergeant Howell (Vince Vaughn) and Captain Glover (Sam Worthington) to conflict, as he cannot fight the enemy. His fellow troops have issues that they cannot count on him on defending them from the enemy. Also being court martial for refusing to carry a weapon. As Doss recalls it, that he is trying to piece everything together and he will not refuse what he believes in while he can still help serve his country. Doss is sent with the troops as a medic in Okinawa, during the battle of the Hacksaw Ridge. Where the Japanese troops held their ground, slaughtering the troops. Doss tends to the wounded and saves them by bringing them back down to base.


 What works great with Mel Gibson's film, is he can manage to make us care for these characters that portrayed in the real event battle. Doss meets some troops that despise him or tried fighting him for being a coward. When the battle lights up, Doss witnesses the horrifying moments of war. When chaos of mortars, turret bunkers, and machine guns firing in all directions. His courage to go out there and back to bring every man back to safety was powerful. Even when he ran into a wounded Japanese soldier, he aided him and left. His one true driving force was his faith, even during the harsh times when men are battling against each other. The film does have a bit of faith theme and a short brief love story with Doss awkwardly falling in love with a nurse Dorothy (Teresa Palmer). His struggle in joining the army through boot training. The final moment of war was powerful and intense. Hacksaw Ridge is a great cinematic war film that does well with showing Doss's courage and the brutal horrifying side of war.

When it comes to directing war films, Mel Gibson has proven himself as the best of the best over the years. From Braveheart to Apocalypto, this man has created tons of entertainment for audiences to enjoy. With his return to the directors chair, he proves once again that he is a master at directing battle sequences with Hacksaw Ridge. This is one of the most raw films I have seen in years. Although it does have a few issues, this is easily one of my favourites of 2016. That is saying a lot, due to the fact that war films have slowly become a thing of the past. For the past couple of years Clint Eastwood has seemed to be the man for the job, but that may all be turning around after this. Here is why Hacksaw Ridge is so impressive.

Although it is based on the true story, which does make it more believable, this is a story that I would never had expected to see up on the big screen. Having an all-out war film about a man who refuses to touch a weapon, due to his past, seemed a bit extreme for a feature film. That being said, the way this film is presented from beginning to end is absolutely breathtaking. Beginning as more of a romance between a unlikely man and woman, it quickly devolves into a gritty tale about a man going off to war, while trying to deal with the fact that his father does not want any more of his sons applying. Against all odds and against every belief of the men on his team, he is brought into war as a medic without a single weapon to protect himself. There is so much to love about this story and it is much more compelling that I was expecting it to be.

Andrew Garfield leads the film as Desmond Doss and this casting could not have been done better. From Vince Vaughn, to Luke Bracey, to Hugo Weaving, and even to Teresa Palmer, the talent surrounding this picture is unparalleled. Ever since Garfield sprung onto the scene and made himself known in The Social Network, I knew he was destined for great things. Never did I think he would be directed by Mel Gibson in a war film, but his physique and quirky performance match the character perfectly. Each side character is given just enough development to care when he needs to save them and in the final act of the film, his actions become some of the most powerful all year.

The most jarring thing that I have to warn viewers about is the fact that this film contains two films in one. For the first half, you focus on the life of Desmond outside of the battlefield, dealing with his personal family life, as well as his love life. It is almost a happy and quirky love story to begin the film, but once he is brought onto the battlefield, my jaw dropped to the floor. Holding nothing back, heads are shown rolling, intestines are seen falling out of bodies, rats are eating the faces of fallen heroes, and machine guns/grenades are tearing men apart. Yes, you come to expect this sort of imagery from a war film, but nobody shoots war sequences like Mel Gibson and it can be a lot to take in at times. If you are expecting a compelling story, followed by extreme war scenes, this is exactly the film you want, but cranked up to eleven. I just feel the need to mention this as some viewers may be turned off.

When it comes to seeing true stories on screen, it all comes down to what the filmmakers choose to include or cut out. Most true stories end with text that describes what happens to each character, following the events of the film. While this film does give you that, I felt like this film robbed its audience of some of that material. The final act feels slightly rushed in an otherwise perfect war film, and that really threw me off. I was sucked into this story from beginning to end, but it ends far too quickly to feel the final impact that the film wants you to. The best emotion that the film delivers is in the heat of battle and the banter between soldiers.

Hacksaw Ridge may have an abrupt ending, not giving enough closure to a few aspects and its jarring war sequences may be a little too much for some viewers, but it truly is an impressive film as a whole. Sprinkling flashbacks and character arcs throughout its duration, it really makes you feel for each character more than you had in each proceeding scene. I found myself transfixed by its fantastic camerawork, compelling screenplay, and hard-hitting direction. Filled with terrific performances all around, Hacksaw Ridge is definitely one of my favourites of 2016. Highly recommended to those who can accept some pretty gory images. "Hacksaw Ridge," stars Andrew Garfield as Desmond Doss, a conscientious objector who enlists into the army not long after the attack on Pearl Harbor, which, in part led America into the Second World War. 
Based upon real life events, the movie follows Doss from childhood to meeting his girlfriend Dorothy Schutte, played by Teresa Palmer, to his enlistment, and his experience at the battle of Okinawa in World War Two. Before Doss hits foreign shores, his first battle comes from the army, as they and the men in his unit try to grasp his beliefs ending most often in intimidating and threatening gestures or worse. Doss's religious beliefs do not allow him to carry a weapon of any sort as a Seventh 
Day Adventist. Vince Vaughn is fantastic as Sargent Howell, and Sam Worthington is just as good as Captain Glover from the 77th Infantry Division with whom Doss is assigned. His unit has a cast of great actors, one of which is Luke Bracey who plays the part of, Smity. Debuting in his first film is Milo Gibson who plays, Lucky Ford. 
The movie is very strong in content depicting combat, with an unflinching front row seat for the horrors of war, as well as heroism. Not since the movie, "Saving Private Ryan," has the cinema brought movie goers this type of realism from the trenches of the battlefield. Mel Gibson directs, "Hacksaw Ridge," his first as a director in ten years, and does a magnificent job in doing so. The entire cast is top notch, led by Garfield as Doss, pulling you into the film and never letting go. 
Mickey and I definitely both highly recommend, "Hacksaw Ridge" as a must see movie, but be forewarned, it is very graphic during the battle scenes.

Hacksaw Ridge would look to be the obligatory war movie of 2016's Oscar season, and it didn't look like much beyond that. Therefore, I wasn't necessarily excited to see it. I've actually never seen a movie directed by Mel Gibson--no, not even The Passion of the Christ--so I can't say how this lines up in his directorial filmography, but it's well made with a general focus on drama and a very good performance from Andrew Garfield, which are enough to save the end product from its occasionally contradictory filmmaking in terms of its depiction of violence. Based on a true story, Desmond T. Doss (Andrew Garfield) is a 20-something pacifist from Virginia in the 1940s. Feeling obliged to serve his country during World War II, he enlists while clearly refusing to use any sort of weaponry, choosing to act as a medic in the field. Eventually he serves in the Battle of Okinawa in Japan, trying to stay true to his convictions throughout. Taking clear inspiration from the no-holds-barred violence of films like Saving Private Ryan, this movie isn't filled with fighting throughout, but when it is, it doesn't pull any punches. The first thing to mention here are the performances, namely that of Garfield. He's just so damn likable that he makes even a few scenes that are awkwardly written in act one feel organic. This is rather rare for me to say, but I didn't see Andrew Garfield while watching the movie--I saw Desmond T. Doss instead. Supporting players like Sam Worthington an Hugo Weaving are good as well, but I was especially surprised to see Vince Vaughn as a drill sergeant and actually buy it. The second he appeared on screen I thought that he'd distract me the entire time, but he didn't, and I feel as if the consistency of the performances speaks to Gibson's ability to get good work from his cast. There isn't much to say from a technical standpoint given that it's all very competently put together, with a realistic look that doesn't overdo the grimy aesthetic and solid editing that makes the war sequences entirely comprehensible instead of butchering everything with a barrage of quick cuts. There are some striking images on display that have nothing to do with the carnage onscreen, and that's one of Hacksaw Ridge's better qualities: it doesn't leave the audience mostly thinking about the violence on display--mostly. The reason I say mostly is that while this movie does a generally good job at not fetishizing the violence or making it look cool, there are some moments where it falters. This is a pacifist film through-and-through, and although I did appreciate some of the depictions of violence such as how displeasing it is to look at instead of being oddly beautiful like a lot of filmmakers do--which is perfectly warranted sometimes--it sometimes loses its way. There are some scenes with the beat progression and tension that would be seen in a horror film but without the fun, and those bits are interesting and effective. However, there are some points where the movie resorts to slow motion and makes the violence seem cooler than was intended. There's also a small stretch of time where the violence becomes numbing instead of staying consistently horrific, and it didn't feel like an intentional choice given how rapid-fire (no pun intended) the film's content is and the short amount of time that the battles take place in. Overall, Hacksaw Ridge is visceral and does what it sets out to do for the most part. Garfield is great here and Andrew Knight and Robert Schenkkan's script does a good job at fleshing him out as a man. Gibson puts together a competent film, but his voice as a filmmaker seems at odds with what's onscreen sometimes. It's not like I was expecting Paths of Glory, but despite Gibson's strengths as a filmmaker, he still has some weaknesses. Regardless, it's fittingly horrific, being simultaneously sad and exciting to watch, with a satisfying ending. 7.2/10, solid, B-, one thumb up, above average, etc.

  This movie honestly floored me. I haven't been emotionally invested in a movie like this in quite a long time. I will be sorely disappointed if this does not get nominated for best picture. Despite your personal feelings about Mel Gibson, you can't argue the fact that he still knows how to make a movie and a damn good one at that. He knows how to film a shot and really knows how to make it effective. The war scenes in this film are some of the best i've ever seen and it instantly reminded me of the war scenes in Saving Private Ryan. They're urgent, cruel, and upsetting, but just like war. The violence is shocking and unrelenting and some of the most vicious and disturbing since, well, Saving Private Ryan. It's mercilessly bloody and urgently violent. You want to look away, but you can't. The cinematography is a thing of pure beauty, it's a marvel to look at. It's visually stunning and incredibly aesthetically pleasing. Andrew Garfield is a revelation and I fully expect him to be nominated for Best Lead Actor if everything is right in the world. He brings charm, humility, and patience to the hero that is Desmond Doss. Not only does he embody the role, he pays acceptable respect to the real life hero. Hugo Weaving is fantastic as Desmond's father and Teresa Palmer is fantastic as his wife. Vince Vaughn really surprised me as well. He's very funny at times, but also commands the screen when prompted too. I won't say what part of the film i'm about to talk about exactly, (you'll know exactly what it is when you see it), but there's a long sequence of Doss becoming the hero that he is, that sequence will stay with me for a long time. It's powerful, beautiful and incredibly moving, just like the entire movie before and after that. Sure we all have heard that "War is hell", but Hacksaw Ridge expertly shows us that it is. It may not be very subtle and it takes a little to get going, but Hacksaw Ridge is one of the best films i've seen all year and it's an incredibly harrowing and moving portrait of an American hero that combines real patriotism, faith and raw brutal war violence. It's a spectacle to behold and one that should not be missed.

Desmond Doss (Andrew Garfield) fue el único soldado americano durante la 2da Guerra Mundial que se rehusó a usar un arma en combate. El hecho de que esta sea una historia real la hace aún más fascinante, y de hecho tuvieron que cortar algunas escenas que sucedieron, pero que fueron tan impresionantes que el público hubiese pensado que fueron inventadas.

En su núcleo, esta es una historia de amor. Los 2 primeros actos presentan a Desmond, su situación familiar y su relación con Dorothy, y cambia de tono completamente cuando es reclutado para la guerra. Las escenas de amor rozan en lo cursi, pero luego cuando empieza la guerra... la película cambia su tono completamente. Las escenas de combate logran capturar el horror de la violencia, y han sido definitivamente el mejor retrato que he visto en mucho tiempo. Especialmente cuando están subiendo las cuerdas para enfrentarse a los japoneses, y el suspenso de no saber que se encontraran arriba, y luego cuando están ahí, ese silencio escalofriante.. la genialidad de esas escenas es testamento de la gran dirección de Mel Gibson. Nadie filma escenas de esa magnitud como Gibson.

Otro aspecto notable de esta película es el respeto con el cual tratan a las creencias religiosas de Desmond, pero sin idealizarlas. Uno como espectador llega a respetar sus creencias, y en ningún momento sientes que te está dando una lección de moralidad.

Las actuaciones son lo que elevan a esta película. Andrew Garfield como Desmond es el casting perfecto, porque este actor además de ser talentoso, le da a sus personajes un toque de ingenuidad, algo que es valioso en este papel, porque uno como público tiene que dudar de él, y luego nos sorprende con su coraje de defender sus creencias sin importar las consecuencias. Pero una de las actuaciones que más me impacto fue la de Hugo Weaving como el padre de Desmond. Es un retrato crudo de las consecuencias que tiene la guerra en los combatientes que logran regresas a sus hogares, y como las pesadillas y los demonios se quedan mucho tiempo después y termina separando familias.

De las mejores películas del 2016.
