There's something beautiful in the film's strictness of morality and hopefulness. Unlike other films of the genre, like Spielberg's "Saving Private Ryan" and Scott's "Black Hawk Down", realism and actuality don't appear to be the goal, as seen in theatrical moments like action film-esque heroics in battle and perfectly crafted moments of melodramatic romance between young Doss and Ms. Dorothy Schutte.

It's a morality tale that tells a moral story in a moral way. A breath of fresh air that holds to true classic Hollywood form in a way that hasn't been seen in a long time. Not perfect, but certainly welcome.

Movie Review: Hacksaw Ridge
Date Viewed: November 12 2016
Directed By Mel Gibson (The Passion of the Christ, Braveheart, Apocalypto and The Man Without a Face)
Written By Andrew Knight and Robert Schenkkan
Starring: Andrew Garfield, Sam Worthington, Hugo Weaving, Vince Vaughn, Luke Bracey, Teresa Palmer, Ryan Corr, Rachel Griffiths, Richard Roxbury, Luke Pegler, Richard Pyros, Ben Mingay and Firass Dirani.

Mel Gibson's "Hacksaw Ridge" tells the story of Desmond T. Doss, an army-medic who saved 75 lives in Okinawa during World War II. This story is preachy and corny at times but it is a harrowing and intense war movie with incredible battle sequences and a terrific performance from Andrew Garfield. Since he was no longer "The Amazing Spider-Man", Garfield was free to do whatever project he wished and "Hacksaw Ridge" is a perfect start to his road in being a mainstream actor. "Hacksaw Ridge" also marks a return to form for Gibson after his many controversies and scandals. This movie is in vein with other bloody and graphic war movies like "Fury", "Platoon" and "Saving Private Ryan" so don't take your kids who are under the age of 14 because this movie will be way too intense for younger viewers.

It maybe intense and disturbing but this is what Gibson is known for, he made "Apocalypto", he directed and starred in his Oscar-winning film "Braveheart" and he made "The Passion of the Christ", which became the biggest religious movie of all time. Gibson shows his responsibility as an artist here again with this solid tribute to faith, valor, bravery and sacrifice.

Desmond T. Doss (Garfield) grew up in Lynchburg, Virginia during the Great Depression where underwent a faithful transition after an incident involving his religious mother (Rachel Griffiths) and troubled war veteran father (Hugo Weaving). Desmond almost killed his father with his own gun but he didn't fire the pistol. After that near-tragic night, he vowed to stick to his religious beliefs and to never fire a weapon as long as he lived.

After delivering an injured man to the hospital, Desmond gets immediately attracted to a nurse named Dorothy Schutte (Teresa Palmer). After dating and falling in love, Desmond and Dorothy get married and he begins to enlist in the Army. Desmond and his brother, Hal (Nathaniel Buzolic) are about to head off to the battlefield but their father is upset because he expects to lose them just as he lost most of childhood buddies.

Due to his beliefs as a conscientious objector, Doss just wants to serve as an army-medic and nothing else. When Doss arrives to his training base in Fort Jackson, South Carolina, he is placed under the strict command of Sergeant Howell (Vince Vaughn) who doesn't take mischief pretty well. Doss immediately becomes an outcast and gets hard labor and beaten by his fellow soldiers due to his belief of not firing a weapon. Things don't get much better as he gets arrested for insubordination. Dorothy convinces him to take the guilty plea so he could be released but Desmond will always stay true to what he believes in so he will try to defy the military court and hope to serve in the army without carrying a weapon.

Of course, Desmond wins his legal battle and he is allowed to join the battlefield without carrying a weapon. When Desmond and his army unit get to Okinawa, the action in "Hacksaw Ridge" really kicks into dramatic gear. We see blood, limbs and body parts splattered all over the battlefield but this is the reality of war. It is not all sunshine and playfulness, war is brutal, intense and truly frightening. Director Mel Gibson captures the reality so well and Andrew Garfield does a remarkable job as Desmond T. Doss. While all the surviving soldiers were safely evacuated, Doss stayed behind so he could save as many lives as he can. He saved 75 brave men that day and he was the first objector to receive the Congressional Medal of Honor.

With fine acting and a perfect balance of gruelling terror and inspiring faith, "Hacksaw Ridge" is a violent war movie that lives up to it's patriotic and religious convictions and I think Gibson and Garfield names will be listed when the Oscar nominations begin rolling out next January.

Coming up to Oscar nomination day, the one film that is going to be interesting is Hacksaw Ridge which is sure to divide some people due to its director Mel Gibson's polarizing persona, but no one can deny he has directed a dandy of a film here straight out of Band of Brothers or even a mix of Saving Private Ryan meets Passion of the Christ focusing on Desmond Doss, a contientious medic who goes to serve during WW2 at one of the bloodiest battles of the war that wasn't D Day and saving over 75 lives without firing a single shot due to his faith not allowing him to carry a gun. It is indeed deserving for recognition particularly for Garfield its lead for convincingly and compassionately playing the titular character, and I wouldn't be surprised if the film itself will be nominated for several technical ones as well and heaven forbid picture after Gibson's own long absence from projects of this scale due to aforementioned issues. Only true faults if anything was the casting of Vince Vaughan who many will find out of place in such a film due to his persona from comedies and attempts initially to go Full Metal Jacket in the opening moments of training which was an unfortunate call showing his weaknesses in drama at least at the moment, and the slight feel that it may have been a film better suited to the late 90's early aughts, but that is only probably due to the long gestation period for someone to pick this project up to direct from development hell and the abundance of WW2 films at that time. Otherwise will it actually beat frontrunners Moonlight or La La Land for the top prize? Doubtful, but I am intrigued how many noms it will receive and what it will mean for Gibson's return to the fold and which projects he will take on next. Solid.
